**London** ^[\[c\]](#cite_note-9)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_United_Kingdom "List of urban areas in the United Kingdom")^[\[d\]](#cite_note-10)^ of both [England](/wiki/England "England") and the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), with a population of 8,866,180 in 2022.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-ONS_mid-year_pop_est-3)^ [Its wider metropolitan area](/wiki/London_metropolitan_area "London metropolitan area") is the largest in [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe"), with a population of 14.9 million.^[\[7\]](#cite_note-11)^ London stands on the [River Thames](/wiki/River_Thames "River Thames") in southeast England, at the head of a 50-mile (80 km) [tidal estuary](/wiki/Tidal_estuary "Tidal estuary") down to the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea"), and has been a major settlement for nearly 2,000 years.^[\[8\]](#cite_note-london_001-12)^ Its ancient core and [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre"), the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London"), was founded by the [Romans](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") as [Londinium](/wiki/Londinium "Londinium") and has retained its medieval boundaries.^[\[e\]](#cite_note-13)^^[\[9\]](#cite_note-14)^ The [City of Westminster](/wiki/City_of_Westminster "City of Westminster"), to the west of the City of London, has been the centuries-long host of [the national government](/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom") and [parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United Kingdom"). London grew rapidly [in the 19th century](/wiki/19th-century_London "19th-century London"), becoming the world's [largest city at the time](/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history "List of largest cities throughout history"). Since the 19th century,^[\[10\]](#cite_note-Mills2-15)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-chambers-16)^ the name "London" has referred to the [metropolis](/wiki/Metropolis "Metropolis") around the City of London, historically split between the [counties](/wiki/Counties_of_England "Counties of England") of [Middlesex](/wiki/Middlesex "Middlesex"), [Essex](/wiki/Essex "Essex"), [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey"), [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent"), and [Hertfordshire](/wiki/Hertfordshire "Hertfordshire"),^[\[12\]](#cite_note-baffling-17)^ which since 1965 has largely comprised the administrative area of [Greater London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London"), governed by [33 local authorities](#Local_government) and the [Greater London Authority](/wiki/Greater_London_Authority "Greater London Authority").^[\[f\]](#cite_note-18)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-politics_uk2-19)^{#cite_ref-politics_uk2_19-0}

As one of the world's major [global cities](/wiki/Global_cities "Global cities"),^[\[14\]](#cite_note-20)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-21)^ London exerts a strong influence on world [art](/wiki/Art_of_London "Art of London"), entertainment, [fashion](/wiki/Fashion_capital "Fashion capital"), commerce, finance, [education](/wiki/Education_in_London "Education in London"), [healthcare](/wiki/Healthcare_in_London "Healthcare in London"), [media](/wiki/Media_in_London "Media in London"), science, technology, [tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_London "Tourism in London"), [transport](/wiki/Transport_in_London "Transport in London"), and communications.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-22)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-23)^ Despite a post-[Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit") exodus of stock listings from the [London Stock Exchange](/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange "London Stock Exchange"),^[\[18\]](#cite_note-LSEExodusToNewYork-24)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-LSEExodus-25)^ London remains a European economic powerhouse,^[\[20\]](#cite_note-London.gov.uk-26)^ and [one of the world's major financial centres](/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index "Global Financial Centres Index"). It hosts Europe's largest concentration of [higher education institutions](/wiki/List_of_universities_and_higher_education_colleges_in_London "List of universities and higher education colleges in London"),^[\[21\]](#cite_note-london2-27)^ some of which are the highest-ranked academic institutions in the world: [Imperial College London](/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London") in [natural](/wiki/Natural_sciences "Natural sciences") and [applied sciences](/wiki/Applied_science "Applied science"), the [London School of Economics](/wiki/London_School_of_Economics "London School of Economics") in [social sciences](/wiki/Social_science "Social science"), and the comprehensive [University College London](/wiki/University_College_London "University College London").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-28)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-29)^ It is the [most visited city](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_international_visitors "List of cities by international visitors") in Europe and has the world's [busiest city airport system](/wiki/List_of_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic "List of busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Busiest_skies-30)^ The [London Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground") is the world's oldest [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") system.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}

London's diverse cultures encompass over 300 languages.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-london_006-32)^ The 2023 population of Greater London of just under 10 million^[\[27\]](#cite_note-33)^ made it Europe's [third-most populous city](/wiki/List_of_European_cities_by_population_within_city_limits "List of European cities by population within city limits"),^[\[28\]](#cite_note-largest_city_eu-34)^ accounting for 13.4% of the United Kingdom's population^[\[29\]](#cite_note-35)^ and over 16% of England's population. The [Greater London Built-up Area](/wiki/Greater_London_Built-up_Area "Greater London Built-up Area") is the [fourth-most populous](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_Europe "List of urban areas in Europe") in Europe, with about 9.8 million inhabitants as of 2011.^[\[3\]](#cite_note-urbanpopulation-4)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-Demographia-36)^ The London metropolitan area is the [third-most populous](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe "List of metropolitan areas in Europe") in Europe, with about 14 million inhabitants as of 2016, making London a [megacity](/wiki/Megacity "Megacity").^[\[g\]](#cite_note-37)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu_show-38)^^[\[32\]](#cite_note-gla-plan-2015-39)^{#cite_ref-gla-plan-2015_39-0}

Four [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") are located in London: [Kew Gardens](/wiki/Kew_Gardens "Kew Gardens"); the [Tower of London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London"); the site featuring the [Palace of Westminster](/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster "Palace of Westminster"), [Church of St. Margaret](/wiki/St_Margaret%27s,_Westminster "St Margaret's, Westminster"), and [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey"); and the historic settlement in [Greenwich](/wiki/Greenwich "Greenwich") where the [Royal Observatory](/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich "Royal Observatory, Greenwich") defines the [prime meridian](/wiki/Prime_meridian_(Greenwich) "Prime meridian (Greenwich)") (0° [longitude](/wiki/Longitude "Longitude")) and [Greenwich Mean Time](/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time "Greenwich Mean Time").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-london_005-40)^ Other landmarks include [Buckingham Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham Palace"), the [London Eye](/wiki/London_Eye "London Eye"), [Piccadilly Circus](/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus "Piccadilly Circus"), [St Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral"), [Tower Bridge](/wiki/Tower_Bridge "Tower Bridge"), and [Trafalgar Square](/wiki/Trafalgar_Square "Trafalgar Square"). The city has the most [museums](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_London "List of museums in London"), art galleries, libraries, and cultural venues in the UK, including the [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum"), [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery "National Gallery"), [Natural History Museum](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London "Natural History Museum, London"), [Tate Modern](/wiki/Tate_Modern "Tate Modern"), [British Library](/wiki/British_Library "British Library"), and numerous [West End](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West End theatre") theatres.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-41)^ Important [sporting events held in London](/wiki/Sport_in_London "Sport in London") include the [FA Cup Final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final"), the [Wimbledon Tennis Championships](/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon"), and the [London Marathon](/wiki/London_Marathon "London Marathon"). It became the first city to host three [Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games") upon hosting the [2012 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics").^[\[35\]](#cite_note-IOC-42)^{#cite_ref-IOC_42-0}  

Toponymy {#Toponymy}
--------------------

Main article: [Etymology of London](/wiki/Etymology_of_London "Etymology of London")

*London* is an ancient name, attested in the first century AD, usually in the [Latinised](/wiki/Latinisation_of_names "Latinisation of names") form *[Londinium](/wiki/Londinium "Londinium")*.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-:2-43)^ Modern scientific analyses of the name must account for the origins of the different forms found in early sources: [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") (usually *Londinium*), [Old English](/wiki/Old_English "Old English") (usually *Lunden*), and [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") (usually *Llundein*), with reference to the known developments over time of sounds in those different languages. It is agreed that the name came into these languages from [Common Brythonic](/wiki/Common_Brittonic "Common Brittonic"); recent work tends to reconstruct the lost Celtic form of the name as \**Londonjon* or something similar. This was then adapted into Latin as *Londinium* and borrowed into Old English.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-auto-44)^{#cite_ref-auto_44-0}

Until 1889, the name "London" applied officially only to the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London"), but since then it has also referred to the [County of London](/wiki/County_of_London "County of London") and to [Greater London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}  

History {#History}
------------------

Main article: [History of London](/wiki/History_of_London "History of London")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of London](/wiki/Timeline_of_London "Timeline of London").  

### Prehistory {#Prehistory}

In 1993, remains of a [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") bridge were found on the south River Thames [foreshore](/wiki/Foreshore "Foreshore"), upstream from [Vauxhall Bridge](/wiki/Vauxhall_Bridge "Vauxhall Bridge").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Denison-46)^ Two of the timbers were [radiocarbon dated](/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating "Radiocarbon dating") to 1750--1285 BC.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Denison-46)^ In 2010, foundations of a large timber structure, dated to 4800--4500 BC,^[\[40\]](#cite_note-47)^ were found on the Thames' south foreshore downstream from Vauxhall Bridge.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Milne-48)^ Both structures are on the south bank of the Thames, where the now-underground [River Effra](/wiki/River_Effra "River Effra") flows into the Thames.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Milne-48)^{#cite_ref-Milne_48-1}  

### Roman London {#Roman_London}

Main article: [Londinium](/wiki/Londinium "Londinium")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg/215px-Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD,_Museum_of_London_(34881481351).jpg)  
Reconstruction drawing of [Londinium](/wiki/Londinium "Londinium") in 120 AD  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/London_Wall_fragment.jpg/215px-London_Wall_fragment.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_Wall_fragment.jpg)  
A surviving section of the 3rd-century [London Wall](/wiki/London_Wall "London Wall") behind [Tower Hill](/wiki/Tower_Hill "Tower Hill")

Despite the evidence of scattered [Brythonic](/wiki/Celtic_Britons "Celtic Britons") settlements in the area, the first major settlement was founded by the [Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") around 47 AD,^[\[1\]](#cite_note-auto1-1)^ about 4 years after their invasion of 43 AD.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-roman-49)^ This only lasted until about 61 AD, when the [Iceni](/wiki/Iceni "Iceni") tribe led by [Queen Boudica](/wiki/Boudica "Boudica") stormed it and burnt it to the ground.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-london_010-50)^{#cite_ref-london_010_50-0}

The next planned incarnation of [Londinium](/wiki/Londinium "Londinium") prospered, superseding [Colchester](/wiki/Colchester "Colchester") as the principal city of the [Roman province](/wiki/Roman_province "Roman province") of [Britannia](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain") in 100. At its height in the 2nd century, Roman London had a population of about 60,000.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}  

### Anglo-Saxon and Viking-period London {#Anglo-Saxon_and_Viking-period_London}

Main article: [Anglo-Saxon London](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_London "Anglo-Saxon London")

With the early 5th-century collapse of Roman rule, the walled city of Londinium was effectively abandoned, although [Roman civilisation](/wiki/Roman_civilisation "Roman civilisation") continued around [St Martin-in-the-Fields](/wiki/St_Martin-in-the-Fields "St Martin-in-the-Fields") until about 450.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-52)^ From about 500, an [Anglo-Saxon](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon "Anglo-Saxon") settlement known as [Lundenwic](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_London "Anglo-Saxon London") developed slightly west of the old Roman city.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-london_011-53)^ By about 680 the city had become a major port again, but there is little evidence of large-scale production. From the 820s repeated [Viking](/wiki/Viking "Viking") assaults brought decline. Three are recorded; those in 851 and 886 succeeded, while the last, in 994, was rebuffed.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Viking_Attacks-54)^{#cite_ref-Viking_Attacks_54-0}

The Vikings applied [Danelaw](/wiki/Danelaw "Danelaw") over much of eastern and northern England, its boundary running roughly from London to [Chester](/wiki/Chester "Chester") as an area of political and geographical control imposed by the Viking incursions formally agreed by the [Danish](/wiki/Danes "Danes") [warlord](/wiki/Warlord "Warlord"), [Guthrum](/wiki/Guthrum "Guthrum") and the [West Saxon](/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_West_Saxons "Kingdom of the West Saxons") king [Alfred the Great](/wiki/Alfred_the_Great "Alfred the Great") in 886. The *[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle")* records that Alfred "refounded" London in 886. Archaeological research shows this involved abandonment of Lundenwic and a revival of life and trade within the old [Roman walls](/wiki/London_Wall "London Wall"). London then grew slowly until a dramatic increase in about 950.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-blackwell-55)^{#cite_ref-blackwell_55-0}

By the 11th century, London was clearly the largest town in England. [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey"), rebuilt in [Romanesque](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture") style by King [Edward the Confessor](/wiki/Edward_the_Confessor "Edward the Confessor"), was one of the grandest churches in Europe. [Winchester](/wiki/Winchester "Winchester") had been the capital of [Anglo-Saxon England](/wiki/History_of_Anglo-Saxon_England "History of Anglo-Saxon England"), but from this time London became the main forum for foreign traders and the base for defence in time of war. In the view of [Frank Stenton](/wiki/Frank_Stenton "Frank Stenton"): "It had the resources, and it was rapidly developing the dignity and the political self-consciousness appropriate to a [national capital](/wiki/National_capital "National capital")."^[\[49\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/220px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg)](/wiki/File:Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto,_1749.jpg) [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey"), as seen in this painting ([Canaletto](/wiki/Canaletto "Canaletto"), 1749), is a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") and one of London's oldest and most important buildings.

After winning the [Battle of Hastings](/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings "Battle of Hastings"), [William, Duke of Normandy](/wiki/William_the_Conqueror "William the Conqueror") was crowned [King of England](/wiki/King_of_England "King of England") in the newly completed [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey") on Christmas Day 1066.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-london_015-57)^ William built the [Tower of London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London"), the first of many such in England rebuilt in stone in the south-eastern corner of the city, to intimidate the inhabitants.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-london_016-58)^ In 1097, [William II](/wiki/William_II_of_England "William II of England") began building [Westminster Hall](/wiki/Westminster_Hall "Westminster Hall"), near the abbey. It became the basis of a new [Palace of Westminster](/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster "Palace of Westminster").^[\[52\]](#cite_note-london_017-59)^{#cite_ref-london_017_59-0}

In the 12th century, the institutions of central government, which had hitherto followed the royal English court around the country, grew in size and sophistication and became increasingly fixed, for most purposes at [Westminster](/wiki/Westminster "Westminster"), although the royal treasury came to rest in the [Tower](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London"). While the [City of Westminster](/wiki/Westminster "Westminster") developed into a true governmental capital, its distinct neighbour, the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London"), remained England's largest city and principal commercial centre and flourished under its own unique administration, the [Corporation of London](/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation "City of London Corporation"). In 1100, its population was some 18,000; by 1300 it had grown to nearly 100,000.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-london_019-60)^ With the [Black Death](/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death") in the mid-14th century, London lost nearly a third of its population.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-61)^ London was the focus of the [Peasants' Revolt](/wiki/Peasants%27_Revolt "Peasants' Revolt") in 1381.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-london_020-62)^{#cite_ref-london_020_62-0}

London was a centre of England's [Jewish population](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_England_(1066%E2%80%931290) "History of the Jews in England (1066–1290)") before their [expulsion](/wiki/Edict_of_Expulsion "Edict of Expulsion") by [Edward I](/wiki/Edward_I_of_England "Edward I of England") in 1290. Violence against Jews occurred in 1190, when it was rumoured that the new king had ordered their massacre after they had presented themselves at his coronation.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-Jacobs-63)^ In 1264 during the [Second Barons' War](/wiki/Second_Barons%27_War "Second Barons' War"), [Simon de Montfort](/wiki/Simon_de_Montfort,_6th_Earl_of_Leicester "Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester")'s rebels killed 500 Jews while attempting to seize records of debts.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-Mundill2010-64)^{#cite_ref-Mundill2010_64-0}  

### Early modern {#Early_modern}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg/170px-Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Siege_of_London_(MS_1168).jpg) The [Lancastrian](/wiki/House_of_Lancaster "House of Lancaster") siege of London in 1471 is attacked by a [Yorkist](/wiki/House_of_York "House of York") sally.

During the [Tudor period](/wiki/Tudor_period "Tudor period"), the [Reformation](/wiki/English_Reformation "English Reformation") produced a gradual shift to [Protestantism](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism"). Much of London property passed from church to private ownership, which accelerated trade and business in the city.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-pevsner-65)^ In 1475, the [Hanseatic League](/wiki/Hanseatic_League "Hanseatic League") set up a main trading base (*[kontor](/wiki/Kontor "Kontor")* ) of England in London, called the *Stalhof* or *[Steelyard](/wiki/Steelyard "Steelyard")* . It remained until 1853, when the Hanseatic cities of [Lübeck](/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck "Lübeck"), [Bremen](/wiki/Bremen "Bremen") and [Hamburg](/wiki/Hamburg "Hamburg") sold the property to [South Eastern Railway](/wiki/South_Eastern_Railway,_UK "South Eastern Railway, UK").^[\[59\]](#cite_note-EB-66)^ [Woollen](/wiki/Woollen "Woollen") cloth was shipped undyed and undressed from 14th/15th century London to the nearby shores of the [Low Countries](/wiki/Low_Countries "Low Countries").^[\[60\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}

Yet English maritime enterprise hardly reached beyond the seas of [north-west Europe](/wiki/Northwestern_Europe "Northwestern Europe"). The commercial route to Italy and the [Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean "Mediterranean") was normally through [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp") and over the [Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps"); any ships passing through the [Strait of Gibraltar](/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar "Strait of Gibraltar") to or from England were likely to be Italian or [Ragusan](/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa "Republic of Ragusa"). The reopening of the Netherlands to English shipping in January 1565 spurred a burst of commercial activity.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-68)^ The [Royal Exchange](/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London "Royal Exchange, London") was founded.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-69)^ [Mercantilism](/wiki/Mercantilism "Mercantilism") grew and monopoly traders such as the [East India Company](/wiki/East_India_Company "East India Company") were founded as trade expanded to the [New World](/wiki/New_World "New World"). London became the main [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") port, with migrants arriving from England and abroad. The population rose from about 50,000 in 1530 to about 225,000 in 1605.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-pevsner-65)^{#cite_ref-pevsner_65-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/220px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg) Map of London in 1593. There is only one bridge across the Thames, but parts of Southwark on the south bank of the river have been developed.

In the 16th century, [William Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare") and his contemporaries lived in London during [English Renaissance theatre](/wiki/English_Renaissance_theatre "English Renaissance theatre"). Shakespeare's [Globe Theatre](/wiki/Globe_Theatre "Globe Theatre") was constructed in 1599 in [Southwark](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Southwark "London Borough of Southwark"). Stage performances came to a halt in London when [Puritan](/wiki/Puritan "Puritan") authorities [shut down the theatres](/wiki/London_theatre_closure_1642 "London theatre closure 1642") in the 1640s.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-70)^ The ban on theatre was lifted during [the Restoration](/wiki/Stuart_Restoration "Stuart Restoration") in 1660, and London's oldest operating theatre, [Drury Lane](/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Drury_Lane "Theatre Royal, Drury Lane"), opened in 1663 in what is now the [West End](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West End theatre") theatre district.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}

By the end of the Tudor period in 1603, London was still compact. There was an assassination attempt on [James I](/wiki/James_I_of_England "James I of England") in Westminster, in the [Gunpowder Plot](/wiki/Gunpowder_Plot "Gunpowder Plot") of 5 November 1605.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-london_023-72)^ In 1637, the government of [Charles I](/wiki/Charles_I_of_England "Charles I of England") attempted to reform administration in the London area. This called for the Corporation of the city to extend its jurisdiction and administration over expanding areas around the city. Fearing an attempt by the Crown to diminish the [Liberties of London](/wiki/Liberties_of_London "Liberties of London"), coupled with a lack of interest in administering these additional areas or concern by city guilds of having to share power, caused the Corporation's "The Great Refusal", a decision which largely continues to account for the unique governmental status of the [City](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London").^[\[66\]](#cite_note-73)^{#cite_ref-73}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/260px-Great_Fire_London.jpg)](/wiki/File:Great_Fire_London.jpg) The [Great Fire of London](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London "Great Fire of London") destroyed many parts of the city in 1666.

In the [English Civil War](/wiki/English_Civil_War "English Civil War"), the majority of Londoners supported the [Parliamentary](/wiki/Roundhead "Roundhead") cause. After an initial advance by the [Royalists](/wiki/Cavaliers "Cavaliers") in 1642, culminating in the battles of [Brentford](/wiki/Battle_of_Brentford_(1642) "Battle of Brentford (1642)") and [Turnham Green](/wiki/Battle_of_Turnham_Green "Battle of Turnham Green"), London was surrounded by a defensive perimeter wall known as the [Lines of Communication](/wiki/Lines_of_Communication_(London) "Lines of Communication (London)"). The lines were built by up to 20,000 people, and were completed in under two months.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-fortified-74)^ The fortifications failed their only test when the [New Model Army](/wiki/New_Model_Army "New Model Army") entered London in 1647,^[\[68\]](#cite_note-75)^ and they were levelled by Parliament the same year.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-fortified-74)^^[\[69\]](#cite_note-76)^ London was [plagued](/wiki/Bubonic_plague "Bubonic plague") by disease in the early 17th century,^[\[70\]](#cite_note-london_024-77)^ culminating in the [Great Plague](/wiki/Great_Plague_of_London "Great Plague of London") of 1665--1666, which killed up to 100,000 people, or a fifth of the population.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-london_024-77)^ The [Great Fire of London](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London "Great Fire of London") broke out in 1666 in Pudding Lane in the city and quickly swept through the wooden buildings.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Samuel_Pepys'_Diary-78)^ Rebuilding took over 10 years and was supervised by polymath [Robert Hooke](/wiki/Robert_Hooke "Robert Hooke").^[\[72\]](#cite_note-london_026-79)^{#cite_ref-london_026_79-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg/170px-Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg) [St Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral") (painted by [Edward Goodall](/wiki/Edward_Angelo_Goodall "Edward Angelo Goodall") in 1850) was completed in 1710

In 1710, [Christopher Wren](/wiki/Christopher_Wren "Christopher Wren")'s masterpiece, [St Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral"), was completed, replacing its medieval predecessor that burned in the Great Fire of 1666. The dome of St Paul's dominated the London skyline for centuries, inspiring the artworks and writing of [William Blake](/wiki/William_Blake "William Blake"), with his 1789 poem "[Holy Thursday](/wiki/Holy_Thursday_(Songs_of_Innocence) "Holy Thursday (Songs of Innocence)")" referring to 'the high dome of Pauls'.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-80)^ During the [Georgian era](/wiki/Georgian_era "Georgian era"), new districts such as [Mayfair](/wiki/Mayfair "Mayfair") were formed in the west; new bridges over the Thames encouraged development in [South London](/wiki/South_London "South London"). In the east, the [Port of London](/wiki/Port_of_London "Port of London") expanded downstream. London's development as an international [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") matured for much of the 18th century.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-Finance_Hub-81)^{#cite_ref-Finance_Hub_81-0}

In 1762, [George III](/wiki/George_III_of_Great_Britain "George III of Great Britain") acquired [Buckingham House](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham Palace"), which was enlarged over the next 75 years. During the 18th century, London was said to be dogged by crime,^[\[75\]](#cite_note-82)^ and the [Bow Street Runners](/wiki/Bow_Street_Runners "Bow Street Runners") were established in 1750 as a professional police force.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-83)^ Epidemics during the 1720s and 30s saw most children born in the city die before reaching their fifth birthday.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}

[Coffee-houses](/wiki/Coffeehouse "Coffeehouse") became a popular place to debate ideas, as growing [literacy](/wiki/Literacy "Literacy") and development of the [printing press](/wiki/Printing_press "Printing press") made news widely available, with [Fleet Street](/wiki/Fleet_Street "Fleet Street") becoming the centre of the British press. The invasion of Amsterdam by Napoleonic armies led many financiers to relocate to London and the first London international issue was arranged in 1817. Around the same time, the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") became the world's leading war fleet, acting as a major deterrent to potential economic adversaries. Following a fire in 1838, the Royal Exchange was redesigned by [William Tite](/wiki/William_Tite "William Tite") and rebuilt in 1844. The repeal of the [Corn Laws](/wiki/Corn_Laws "Corn Laws") in 1846 was specifically aimed at weakening Dutch economic power. London then overtook Amsterdam as the leading international financial centre.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-auto2-85)^{#cite_ref-auto2_85-0}  

### Late modern and contemporary {#Late_modern_and_contemporary}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-220px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London,_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif) The [Royal Exchange](/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London "Royal Exchange, London") in 1886. It was founded in 1571 (with the present building rebuilt in 1844) as a centre of commerce for the City of London.

With the onset of the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution") in Britain, an unprecedented growth in [urbanisation](/wiki/Urbanisation "Urbanisation") took place, and the number of [High Streets](/wiki/High_Street "High Street") (the primary street for retail in Britain) rapidly grew.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-Sales-86)^^[\[80\]](#cite_note-87)^ London was the world's [largest city from about 1831 to 1925](/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history "List of largest cities throughout history"), with a population density of 802 per acre (325 per hectare).^[\[81\]](#cite_note-london_030-88)^ In addition to the growing number of stores selling goods, such as [Harding, Howell \& Co.](/wiki/Harding,_Howell_%26_Co. "Harding, Howell & Co.")---one of the first [department stores](/wiki/Department_store "Department store")---located on [Pall Mall](/wiki/Pall_Mall,_London "Pall Mall, London"), the streets had scores of [street sellers](/wiki/Hawker_(trade) "Hawker (trade)").^[\[79\]](#cite_note-Sales-86)^ London's overcrowded conditions led to [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") epidemics, claiming 14,000 lives in 1848, and 6,000 in 1866.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-89)^ Rising [traffic congestion](/wiki/Traffic_congestion "Traffic congestion") led to the creation of the [London Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground"), the world's first [urban rail network](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit").^[\[83\]](#cite_note-90)^ The [Metropolitan Board of Works](/wiki/Metropolitan_Board_of_Works "Metropolitan Board of Works") oversaw infrastructure expansion in the capital and some surrounding counties; it was abolished in 1889 when the [London County Council](/wiki/London_County_Council "London County Council") was created out of county areas surrounding the capital.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}

From the early years of the 20th century onwards, [teashops](/wiki/Tea_in_the_United_Kingdom#Tea_rooms "Tea in the United Kingdom") were found on High Streets across London and the rest of Britain, with [Lyons](/wiki/J._Lyons_and_Co. "J. Lyons and Co."), who opened the first of their [chain](/wiki/Chain_store "Chain store") of teashops in [Piccadilly](/wiki/Piccadilly "Piccadilly") in 1894, leading the way.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-92)^ The tearooms, such as the [Criterion](/wiki/Criterion_Restaurant "Criterion Restaurant") in Piccadilly, became a popular meeting place for women from the suffrage movement.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-93)^ The city was the target of many attacks during the [suffragette bombing and arson campaign](/wiki/Suffragette_bombing_and_arson_campaign "Suffragette bombing and arson campaign"), between 1912 and 1914, which saw historic landmarks such as [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey") and [St Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral") bombed.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/220px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg)](/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg)  
British volunteer recruits in London, August 1914, during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/220px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg)](/wiki/File:LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg)  
A bombed-out London street during [the Blitz](/wiki/The_Blitz "The Blitz"), [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")

London was [bombed by the Germans](/wiki/German_strategic_bombing_during_World_War_I "German strategic bombing during World War I") in the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War"), and during the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War"), [the Blitz](/wiki/The_Blitz "The Blitz") and other bombings by the German *[Luftwaffe](/wiki/Luftwaffe "Luftwaffe")* killed over 30,000 Londoners, destroying large tracts of housing and other buildings across the city.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-95)^ The tomb of [the Unknown Warrior](/wiki/The_Unknown_Warrior "The Unknown Warrior"), an unidentified member of the British armed forces killed during the First World War, was buried in Westminster Abbey on 11 November 1920.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-96)^ [The Cenotaph](/wiki/The_Cenotaph "The Cenotaph"), located in [Whitehall](/wiki/Whitehall "Whitehall"), was unveiled on the same day, and is the focal point for the [National Service of Remembrance](/wiki/National_Service_of_Remembrance "National Service of Remembrance") held annually on [Remembrance Sunday](/wiki/Remembrance_Sunday "Remembrance Sunday"), the closest Sunday to 11 November.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}

The [1948 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics "1948 Summer Olympics") were held at the original [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923) "Wembley Stadium (1923)"), while London was still recovering from the war.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-98)^ From the 1940s, London became home to many immigrants, primarily from [Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") countries such as Jamaica, India, Bangladesh and Pakistan,^[\[92\]](#cite_note-99)^ making London one of the most diverse cities in the world. In 1951, the [Festival of Britain](/wiki/Festival_of_Britain "Festival of Britain") was held on the [South Bank](/wiki/South_Bank "South Bank").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-100)^ The [Great Smog](/wiki/Great_Smog "Great Smog") of 1952 led to the [Clean Air Act 1956](/wiki/Clean_Air_Act_1956 "Clean Air Act 1956"), which ended the "[pea soup fogs](/wiki/Pea_soup_fog "Pea soup fog")" for which London had been notorious, and had earned it the nickname the "Big Smoke".^[\[94\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}

Starting mainly in the mid-1960s, London became a centre for worldwide [youth culture](/wiki/Youth_culture "Youth culture"), exemplified by the [Swinging London](/wiki/Swinging_London "Swinging London") sub-culture associated with the [King's Road](/wiki/King%27s_Road "King's Road"), [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea,_London "Chelsea, London") and [Carnaby Street](/wiki/Carnaby_Street "Carnaby Street").^[\[95\]](#cite_note-102)^ The role of trendsetter revived in the [punk](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock") era.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-103)^ In 1965 London's political boundaries were expanded in response to the growth of the urban area and a new [Greater London Council](/wiki/Greater_London_Council "Greater London Council") was created.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-104)^ During [The Troubles](/wiki/The_Troubles "The Troubles") in Northern Ireland, London was hit from 1973 by bomb attacks by the [Provisional Irish Republican Army](/wiki/Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army "Provisional Irish Republican Army").^[\[98\]](#cite_note-bombings-105)^ These attacks lasted for two decades, starting with the [Old Bailey bombing](/wiki/Old_Bailey_bombing "Old Bailey bombing").^[\[98\]](#cite_note-bombings-105)^ Racial inequality was highlighted by the [1981 Brixton riot](/wiki/1981_Brixton_riot "1981 Brixton riot").^[\[99\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

Greater London's population declined in the decades after the Second World War, from an estimated peak of 8.6 million in 1939 to around 6.8 million in the 1980s.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-107)^ The principal ports for London moved downstream to [Felixstowe](/wiki/Port_of_Felixstowe "Port of Felixstowe") and [Tilbury](/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury "Port of Tilbury"), with the [London Docklands](/wiki/London_Docklands "London Docklands") area becoming a focus for regeneration, including the [Canary Wharf](/wiki/Canary_Wharf "Canary Wharf") development. This was born out of London's increasing role as an international financial centre in the 1980s.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-108)^ Located about 2 miles (3 km) east of central London, the [Thames Barrier](/wiki/Thames_Barrier "Thames Barrier") was completed in the 1980s to protect London against tidal surges from the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea").^[\[102\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}

The Greater London Council was abolished in 1986, leaving London with no central administration until 2000 and the creation of the [Greater London Authority](/wiki/Greater_London_Authority "Greater London Authority").^[\[103\]](#cite_note-110)^ To mark the 21st century, the [Millennium Dome](/wiki/Millennium_Dome "Millennium Dome"), [London Eye](/wiki/London_Eye "London Eye") and [Millennium Bridge](/wiki/Millennium_Bridge_(London) "Millennium Bridge (London)") were constructed.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-111)^ On 6 July 2005 London was awarded the [2012 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics"), as the first city to stage the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games") three times.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-IOC-42)^ On 7 July 2005, three London Underground trains and a double-decker bus were bombed in a [series of terrorist attacks](/wiki/7_July_2005_London_bombings "7 July 2005 London bombings").^[\[98\]](#cite_note-bombings-105)^{#cite_ref-bombings_105-2}

In 2008, *[Time](/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")* named London alongside New York City and Hong Kong as [Nylonkong](/wiki/Nylonkong "Nylonkong"), hailing them as the world's three most influential [global cities](/wiki/Global_cities "Global cities").^[\[105\]](#cite_note-112)^ In January 2015, Greater London's population was estimated to be 8.63 million, its highest since 1939.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-gla-pop-2015-113)^ During the [Brexit referendum](/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum "2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum") in 2016, the UK as a whole decided to leave the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), but most London constituencies voted for remaining.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-114)^ However, Britain's [exit from the EU](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit") in early 2020 only marginally weakened London's position as an international financial centre.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}  

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

### Local government {#Local_government}

Main articles: [Local government in London](/wiki/Local_government_in_London "Local government in London"), [History of local government in London](/wiki/History_of_local_government_in_London "History of local government in London"), and [List of heads of London government](/wiki/List_of_heads_of_London_government "List of heads of London government")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:City_coat_of_arms,_Holborn_Viaduct_(cropped).jpg) [Arms of the Corporation of the City of London](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_the_City_of_London "Coat of arms of the City of London")^[\[109\]](#cite_note-116)^

The administration of London is formed of two tiers: a citywide, strategic tier and a local tier. Citywide administration is coordinated by the [Greater London Authority](/wiki/Greater_London_Authority "Greater London Authority") (GLA), while local administration is carried out by 33 smaller authorities.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-london_032-117)^ The GLA consists of two elected components: the [mayor of London](/wiki/Mayor_of_London "Mayor of London"), who has [executive powers](/wiki/Executive_powers "Executive powers"), and the [London Assembly](/wiki/London_Assembly "London Assembly"), which scrutinises the mayor's decisions and can accept or reject the mayor's budget proposals each year. The GLA has responsibility for the majority of London's transport system through its functional arm [Transport for London](/wiki/Transport_for_London "Transport for London") (TfL), it is responsible for overseeing the city's police and fire services, and also for setting a strategic vision for London on a range of issues.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-london_goverance-118)^ The headquarters of the GLA is [City Hall](/wiki/City_Hall,_Newham "City Hall, Newham"), Newham. The mayor since 2016 has been [Sadiq Khan](/wiki/Sadiq_Khan "Sadiq Khan"), the first [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") mayor of a major Western capital.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-119)^ The mayor's [statutory planning](/wiki/Statutory_planning "Statutory planning") strategy is published as the [London Plan](/wiki/London_Plan "London Plan"), which was most recently revised in 2011.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-london_plan-120)^{#cite_ref-london_plan_120-0}

The local authorities are the councils of the 32 [London boroughs](/wiki/London_boroughs "London boroughs") and the [City of London Corporation](/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation "City of London Corporation").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-london_035-121)^ They are responsible for most local services, such as local planning, schools, libraries, leisure and recreation, [social services](/wiki/Social_work "Social work"), local roads and refuse collection.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-122)^ Certain functions, such as [waste management](/wiki/Waste_disposal_authorities_in_London "Waste disposal authorities in London"), are provided through joint arrangements. In 2009--2010 the combined revenue expenditure by London councils and the GLA amounted to just over £22 billion (£14.7 billion for the boroughs and £7.4 billion for the GLA).^[\[116\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

The [London Fire Brigade](/wiki/London_Fire_Brigade "London Fire Brigade") is the [statutory](/wiki/Statute "Statute") [fire and rescue service](/wiki/Fire_service_in_the_UK "Fire service in the UK") for Greater London, run by the [London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority](/wiki/London_Fire_and_Emergency_Planning_Authority "London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority"). It is the third largest fire service in the world.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-LFB-124)^ [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service "National Health Service") [ambulance services](/wiki/Emergency_medical_services "Emergency medical services") are provided by the [London Ambulance Service (LAS) NHS Trust](/wiki/London_Ambulance_Service "London Ambulance Service"), the largest free-at-the-point-of-use emergency ambulance service in the world.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-LAS-125)^ The [London Air Ambulance](/wiki/London_Air_Ambulance "London Air Ambulance") charity operates in conjunction with the LAS where required. [Her Majesty's Coastguard](/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Coastguard "Her Majesty's Coastguard") and the [Royal National Lifeboat Institution](/wiki/Royal_National_Lifeboat_Institution "Royal National Lifeboat Institution") operate on the [River Thames](/wiki/River_Thames "River Thames"), which is under the jurisdiction of the [Port of London Authority](/wiki/Port_of_London_Authority "Port of London Authority") from [Teddington Lock](/wiki/Teddington_Lock "Teddington Lock") to the sea.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}  

### National government {#National_government}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/190px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_(cropped).jpg) [10 Downing Street](/wiki/10_Downing_Street "10 Downing Street"), official residence of the [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the United Kingdom")

London is the seat of the [Government of the United Kingdom](/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom"). Many government departments, as well as the [prime minister's](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the United Kingdom") residence at [10 Downing Street](/wiki/10_Downing_Street "10 Downing Street"), are based close to the [Palace of Westminster](/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster "Palace of Westminster"), particularly along [Whitehall](/wiki/Whitehall "Whitehall").^[\[120\]](#cite_note-london_036-127)^ There are 75 members of [Parliament](/wiki/British_House_of_Commons "British House of Commons") (MPs) from London; As of [June 2024](/wiki/2024_United_Kingdom_general_election "2024 United Kingdom general election"), 59 are from the [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)"), 9 are [Conservatives](/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK) "Conservative Party (UK)"), 6 are [Liberal Democrats](/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_(UK) "Liberal Democrats (UK)") and one constituency is held by an [independent](/wiki/Independent_politician "Independent politician").^[\[121\]](#cite_note-128)^ The ministerial post of [minister for London](/wiki/Minister_for_London "Minister for London") was created in 1994, however as of 2024, the post has been vacant.{#cite_ref-128}  

### Policing and crime {#Policing_and_crime}

Main article: [Crime in London](/wiki/Crime_in_London "Crime in London")

Policing in Greater London, with the exception of the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London"), is provided by the [Metropolitan Police](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police "Metropolitan Police") ("The Met"), overseen by the mayor through the [Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime](/wiki/Mayor%27s_Office_for_Policing_and_Crime "Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime") (MOPAC).^[\[122\]](#cite_note-129)^ The Met is also referred to as [Scotland Yard](/wiki/Scotland_Yard "Scotland Yard") after the location of its original headquarters in a road called [Great Scotland Yard](/wiki/Great_Scotland_Yard "Great Scotland Yard") in Whitehall. The City of London has its own police force -- the [City of London Police](/wiki/City_of_London_Police "City of London Police").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-Policing-130)^ First worn by Met police officers in 1863, the [custodian helmet](/wiki/Custodian_helmet "Custodian helmet") has been called a "cultural icon" and a "symbol of British law enforcement".^[\[124\]](#cite_note-131)^ Introduced by the Met in 1929, the blue [police telephone box](/wiki/Police_box "Police box") (basis for the [TARDIS](/wiki/TARDIS "TARDIS") in *[Doctor Who](/wiki/Doctor_Who "Doctor Who")* ) was once a common sight throughout London and regional cities in the UK.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg/240px-SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:SIS_building_(26327425611).jpg) Headquarters of [MI6](/wiki/MI6 "MI6"), the UK's foreign intelligence service, at the [SIS Building](/wiki/SIS_Building "SIS Building"). Scenes featuring [James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond") (the fictional MI6 agent) have been filmed here.

The [British Transport Police](/wiki/British_Transport_Police "British Transport Police") are responsible for police services on [National Rail](/wiki/National_Rail "National Rail"), [London Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground"), [Docklands Light Railway](/wiki/Docklands_Light_Railway "Docklands Light Railway") and [Tramlink](/wiki/Tramlink "Tramlink") services.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-BTP-133)^ The [Ministry of Defence Police](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_Police "Ministry of Defence Police") is a special police force in London, which does not generally become involved with policing the general public.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-134)^ The UK's domestic counter-intelligence service ([MI5](/wiki/MI5 "MI5")) is headquartered in [Thames House](/wiki/Thames_House "Thames House") on the north bank of the River Thames and the foreign intelligence service ([MI6](/wiki/MI6 "MI6")) is headquartered in the [SIS Building](/wiki/SIS_Building "SIS Building") on the south bank.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

Crime rates vary widely across different areas of London. Crime figures are made available nationally at [Local Authority](/wiki/Local_authority#England "Local authority") and [Ward](/wiki/Ward_(England) "Ward (England)") level.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-136)^ In 2015, there were 118 homicides, a 25.5% increase over 2014.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-137)^ Recorded crime has been rising in London, notably violent crime and murder by stabbing and other means have risen. There were 50 murders from the start of 2018 to mid April 2018. Funding cuts to police in London are likely to have contributed to this, though other factors are involved.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-138)^ However, homicide figures fell in 2022 with 109 recorded for the year, and the murder rate in London is much lower than [other major cities](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_homicide_rate "List of cities by homicide rate") around the world.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-139)^{#cite_ref-139}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

Main article: [Geography of London](/wiki/Geography_of_London "Geography of London")  

### Scope {#Scope}

London, also known as [Greater London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London"), is one of nine [regions of England](/wiki/Regions_of_England "Regions of England") and the top subdivision covering most of the city's metropolis. The [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London") at its core once comprised the whole settlement, but as its urban area grew, the [Corporation of London](/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation "City of London Corporation") resisted attempts to amalgamate the city with its [suburbs](/wiki/Suburbs "Suburbs"), causing "London" to be defined several ways.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-chancery-140)^{#cite_ref-chancery_140-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg) Satellite view of London in June 2018

Forty percent of Greater London is covered by the [London post town](/wiki/London_postal_district "London postal district"), in which 'London' forms part of postal addresses.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-london_042-141)^ The London telephone [area code](/wiki/Area_code "Area code") (020) covers a larger area, similar in size to Greater London, although some outer districts are excluded and some just outside included. The Greater London boundary has been [aligned to the M25 motorway](/wiki/List_of_Greater_London_boundary_changes "List of Greater London boundary changes") in places.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-london_044-142)^{#cite_ref-london_044_142-0}

Further urban expansion is now prevented by the [Metropolitan Green Belt](/wiki/Metropolitan_Green_Belt "Metropolitan Green Belt"), although the built-up area extends beyond the boundary in places, producing a separately defined [Greater London Urban Area](/wiki/Greater_London_Urban_Area "Greater London Urban Area"). Beyond this is the vast [London commuter belt](/wiki/London_commuter_belt "London commuter belt").^[\[136\]](#cite_note-london_041-143)^ Greater London is split for some purposes into [Inner London](/wiki/Inner_London "Inner London") and [Outer London](/wiki/Outer_London "Outer London"),^[\[137\]](#cite_note-london_045-144)^ and by the River Thames into [North](/wiki/North_London "North London") and [South](/wiki/South_London "South London"), with an informal [central London](/wiki/Central_London "Central London") area. The coordinates of the nominal centre of London, traditionally the original [Eleanor Cross](/wiki/Eleanor_Cross "Eleanor Cross") at [Charing Cross](/wiki/Charing_Cross "Charing Cross") near the junction of [Trafalgar Square](/wiki/Trafalgar_Square "Trafalgar Square") and [Whitehall](/wiki/Whitehall "Whitehall"), are about [51°30′26″N 00°07′39″W﻿ / ﻿51.50722°N 0.12750°W﻿ / 51.50722; -0.12750](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=London&params=51_30_26_N_00_07_39_W_type:city(7,000,000)_region:GB).^[\[138\]](#cite_note-london_039-145)^{#cite_ref-london_039_145-0}  

### Status {#Status}

Within London, both the City of London and the [City of Westminster](/wiki/City_of_Westminster "City of Westminster") have [city status](/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom "City status in the United Kingdom"). The City of London and the remainder of Greater London are both [counties for the purposes of lieutenancies](/wiki/Ceremonial_counties_of_England "Ceremonial counties of England").^[\[139\]](#cite_note-london_049-146)^ The area of [Greater London](/wiki/Metropolitan_and_non-metropolitan_counties_of_England#Greater_London "Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England") includes areas that are part of the [historic counties](/wiki/Historic_counties_of_England "Historic counties of England") of [Middlesex](/wiki/Middlesex "Middlesex"), [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent"), [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey"), [Essex](/wiki/Essex "Essex") and [Hertfordshire](/wiki/Hertfordshire "Hertfordshire").^[\[140\]](#cite_note-london_050-147)^ More recently, Greater London has been defined as a [region of England](/wiki/Regions_of_England "Regions of England") and in this context is known as *London* .^[\[141\]](#cite_note-148)^{#cite_ref-148}

It is the capital of the United Kingdom and of England by [convention](/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_custom) "Constitutional convention (political custom)") rather than statute. The capital of England was moved to London from [Winchester](/wiki/Winchester "Winchester") as the [Palace of Westminster](/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster "Palace of Westminster") developed in the 12th and 13th centuries to become the permanent location of the [royal court](/wiki/Noble_court "Noble court"), and thus the political capital of the nation.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-london_060-149)^{#cite_ref-london_060_149-0}  

### Topography {#Topography}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/220px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg) London from [Primrose Hill](/wiki/Primrose_Hill "Primrose Hill")

Greater London encompasses a total area of 611 square miles (1,583 km^2^) an area which had a population of 7,172,036 in 2001 and a population density of 11,760 inhabitants per square mile (4,542/km^2^). The extended area known as the London Metropolitan Region or the London Metropolitan Agglomeration, comprises a total area of 3,236 square miles (8,382 km^2^) has a population of 13,709,000 and a population density of 3,900 inhabitants per square mile (1,510/km^2^).^[\[143\]](#cite_note-Metrop-150)^{#cite_ref-Metrop_150-0}

Modern London stands on the [Thames](/wiki/River_Thames "River Thames"), its primary geographical feature, a [navigable](/wiki/Navigability "Navigability") river which crosses the city from the south-west to the east. The [Thames Valley](/wiki/Thames_Valley "Thames Valley") is a [flood plain](/wiki/Floodplain "Floodplain") surrounded by gently rolling hills including [Parliament Hill](/wiki/Parliament_Hill,_London "Parliament Hill, London"), [Addington Hills](/wiki/Addington_Hills "Addington Hills"), and [Primrose Hill](/wiki/Primrose_Hill "Primrose Hill"). Historically London grew up at the [lowest bridging point](/wiki/Lowest_bridging_point "Lowest bridging point") on the Thames. The Thames was once a much broader, shallower river with extensive [marshlands](/wiki/Marsh "Marsh"); at high tide, its shores reached five times their present width.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-london_065-151)^{#cite_ref-london_065_151-0}

Since the [Victorian era](/wiki/Victorian_era "Victorian era") the Thames has been extensively [embanked](/wiki/Thames_Embankment "Thames Embankment"), and many of its London [tributaries](/wiki/Tributaries_of_the_River_Thames "Tributaries of the River Thames") now flow [underground](/wiki/Subterranean_rivers_of_London "Subterranean rivers of London"). The Thames is a tidal river, and London is vulnerable to flooding.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-london_066-152)^ The threat has increased over time because of a slow but continuous rise in [high water](/wiki/Tide "Tide") level caused by [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change") and by the slow 'tilting' of the British Isles as a result of [post-glacial rebound](/wiki/Post-glacial_rebound "Post-glacial rebound").^[\[146\]](#cite_note-london_067-153)^{#cite_ref-london_067_153-0}  

### Climate {#Climate}

Main article: [Climate of London](/wiki/Climate_of_London "Climate of London")

London has a temperate [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Cfb* ). Rainfall records have been kept in the city since at least 1697, when records began at [Kew](/wiki/Kew "Kew"). At Kew, the most rainfall in one month is 7.4 inches (189 mm) in November 1755 and the least is 0 inches (0 mm) in both December 1788 and July 1800. Mile End also had 0 inches (0 mm) in April 1893.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-154)^ The wettest year on record is 1903, with a total fall of 38.1 inches (969 mm) and the driest is 1921, with a total fall of 12.1 inches (308 mm).^[\[148\]](#cite_note-155)^ The average annual precipitation amounts to about 600mm, which is half the annual rainfall of [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-156)^ Despite relatively low annual precipitation, London receives 109.6 rainy days on the 1.0mm threshold annually. London is vulnerable to [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_Kingdom "Climate change in the United Kingdom"), and there is concern among [hydrological](/wiki/Hydrology "Hydrology") experts that households may run out of water before 2050.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-157)^{#cite_ref-157}

Temperature extremes in London range from 40.2 °C (104.4 °F) at Heathrow on 19 July 2022 down to −17.4 °C (0.7 °F) at Northolt on 13 December 1981.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-158)^^[\[152\]](#cite_note-159)^ Records for [atmospheric pressure](/wiki/Atmospheric_pressure "Atmospheric pressure") have been kept at London since 1692. The highest pressure ever reported is 1,049.8 millibars (31.00 inHg) on 20 January 2020.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}

Summers are generally warm, sometimes hot. London's average July high is 23.5 °C (74.3 °F). On average each year, London experiences 31 days above 25 °C (77.0 °F) and 4.2 days above 30.0 °C (86.0 °F). During the [2003 European heat wave](/wiki/2003_European_heat_wave "2003 European heat wave"), prolonged heat led to hundreds of heat-related deaths.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-161)^ A previous spell of 15 consecutive days above 32.2 °C (90.0 °F) in England in 1976 also caused many heat related deaths.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-162)^ A previous temperature of 37.8 °C (100.0 °F) in August 1911 at the Greenwich station was later disregarded as non-standard.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-metoffice.gov.uk-163)^ Droughts can also, occasionally, be a problem, especially in summer, most recently in summer 2018, and with much drier than average conditions prevailing from May to December.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-164)^ However, the most consecutive days without rain was 73 days in the spring of 1893.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}

Winters are generally cool with little temperature variation. Heavy snow is rare but snow usually falls at least once each winter. Spring and autumn can be pleasant. As a large city, London has a considerable [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect,^[\[159\]](#cite_note-166)^ making the centre of London at times 5 °C (9 °F) warmer than the suburbs and outskirts.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}

### Areas {#Areas}

Main articles: [List of areas of London](/wiki/List_of_areas_of_London "List of areas of London") and [London boroughs](/wiki/London_boroughs "London boroughs")

Places within London's vast urban area are identified using area names, such as [Mayfair](/wiki/Mayfair "Mayfair"), [Southwark](/wiki/Southwark "Southwark"), [Wembley](/wiki/Wembley "Wembley"), and [Whitechapel](/wiki/Whitechapel "Whitechapel"). These are either informal designations, reflect the names of villages that have been absorbed by sprawl, or are superseded administrative units such as parishes or [former boroughs](/wiki/Metropolitan_boroughs_of_the_County_of_London "Metropolitan boroughs of the County of London").^[\[170\]](#cite_note-178)^{#cite_ref-178}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/290px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_(44761485915).jpg) The [West End theatre](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West End theatre") district in 2016

Such names have remained in use through tradition, each referring to a local area with its own distinctive character, but without official boundaries. Since 1965, Greater London has been divided into 32 [London boroughs](/wiki/London_borough "London borough") in addition to the ancient City of London.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-london_071-179)^ The City of London is the main financial district,^[\[172\]](#cite_note-london_073-180)^ and [Canary Wharf](/wiki/Canary_Wharf "Canary Wharf") has recently developed into a new financial and commercial hub in the [Docklands](/wiki/London_Docklands "London Docklands") to the east.{#cite_ref-london_073_180-0}

The [West End](/wiki/West_End_of_London "West End of London") is London's main entertainment and shopping district, attracting tourists.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-181)^ [West London](/wiki/West_(London_sub_region) "West (London sub region)") includes expensive residential areas where properties can sell for tens of millions of pounds.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-182)^ The average price for properties in [Kensington and Chelsea](/wiki/Royal_Borough_of_Kensington_and_Chelsea "Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea") is over £2 million with a similarly high outlay in most of central London.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-183)^^[\[176\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}

The [East End](/wiki/East_End_of_London "East End of London") is the area closest to the original [Port of London](/wiki/Port_of_London "Port of London"), known for its high immigrant population, as well as for being one of the poorest areas in London.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-East_End-185)^ The surrounding [East London](/wiki/North_East_(London_sub_region) "North East (London sub region)") area saw much of London's early industrial development; now, [brownfield](/wiki/Brownfield_land "Brownfield land") sites throughout the area are being redeveloped as part of the [Thames Gateway](/wiki/Thames_Gateway "Thames Gateway") including the [London Riverside](/wiki/London_Riverside "London Riverside") and [Lower Lea Valley](/wiki/Lower_Lea_Valley "Lower Lea Valley"), which was developed into the [Olympic Park](/wiki/Olympic_Park,_London "Olympic Park, London") for the [2012 Olympics and Paralympics](/wiki/London_2012_Olympic_bid "London 2012 Olympic bid").^[\[177\]](#cite_note-East_End-185)^{#cite_ref-East_End_185-1}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

Main articles: [Architecture of London](/wiki/Architecture_of_London "Architecture of London"), [List of tallest buildings and structures in London](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures_in_London "List of tallest buildings and structures in London"), and [List of demolished buildings and structures in London](/wiki/List_of_demolished_buildings_and_structures_in_London "List of demolished buildings and structures in London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/260px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg) The [Tower of London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London"), a medieval castle, dating in part to 1078

London's buildings are too diverse to be characterised by any particular architectural style, partly because of their varying ages. Many grand houses and public buildings, such as the [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery "National Gallery"), are constructed from [Portland stone](/wiki/Portland_stone "Portland stone"). Some areas of the city, particularly those just west of the centre, are characterised by white [stucco](/wiki/Stucco "Stucco") or whitewashed buildings. Few structures in central London pre-date the [Great Fire](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London "Great Fire of London") of 1666, these being a few trace [Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") remains, the [Tower of London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London") and a few scattered [Tudor](/wiki/Tudor_architecture "Tudor architecture") survivors in the city. Further out is, for example, the Tudor-period [Hampton Court Palace](/wiki/Hampton_Court_Palace "Hampton Court Palace").^[\[178\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

Part of the varied architectural heritage are the 17th-century churches by [Christopher Wren](/wiki/Christopher_Wren "Christopher Wren"), neoclassical financial institutions such as the [Royal Exchange](/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London "Royal Exchange, London") and the [Bank of England](/wiki/Bank_of_England "Bank of England"), to the early 20th century [Old Bailey](/wiki/Old_Bailey "Old Bailey") courthouse and the 1960s [Barbican Estate](/wiki/Barbican_Estate "Barbican Estate"). The 1939 [Battersea Power Station](/wiki/Battersea_Power_Station "Battersea Power Station") by the river in the south-west is a local landmark, while some railway termini are excellent examples of [Victorian architecture](/wiki/Victorian_architecture "Victorian architecture"), most notably [St. Pancras](/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station "St Pancras railway station") and [Paddington](/wiki/Paddington_railway_station "Paddington railway station").^[\[179\]](#cite_note-london_078-187)^ The density of London varies, with high employment density in the [central area](/wiki/Central_London "Central London") and [Canary Wharf](/wiki/Canary_Wharf "Canary Wharf"), high residential densities in [inner London](/wiki/Inner_London "Inner London"), and lower densities in [Outer London](/wiki/Outer_London "Outer London").{#cite_ref-london_078_187-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Buckingham_Palace_from_side,_London,_UK_-_Diliff.jpg) The east wing public façade of [Buckingham Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham Palace") was built between 1847 and 1850; it was remodelled to its present form in 1913. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/220px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg) [Trafalgar Square](/wiki/Trafalgar_Square "Trafalgar Square") and its fountains, with [Nelson's Column](/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column "Nelson's Column") on the right

[The Monument](/wiki/The_Monument "The Monument") in the City of London provides views of the surrounding area while commemorating the [Great Fire of London](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London "Great Fire of London"), which originated nearby. [Marble Arch](/wiki/Marble_Arch "Marble Arch") and [Wellington Arch](/wiki/Wellington_Arch "Wellington Arch"), at the north and south ends of [Park Lane](/wiki/Park_Lane_(road) "Park Lane (road)"), respectively, have royal connections, as do the [Albert Memorial](/wiki/Albert_Memorial "Albert Memorial") and [Royal Albert Hall](/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall "Royal Albert Hall") in [Kensington](/wiki/Kensington "Kensington"). [Nelson's Column](/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column "Nelson's Column") (built to commemorate [Admiral Horatio Nelson](/wiki/Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson "Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson")) is a nationally recognised monument in [Trafalgar Square](/wiki/Trafalgar_Square "Trafalgar Square"), one of the focal points of central London. Older buildings are mainly brick, commonly the yellow [London stock brick](/wiki/London_stock_brick "London stock brick").^[\[180\]](#cite_note-london_077-188)^{#cite_ref-london_077_188-0}

In the dense areas, most of the concentration is via medium- and high-rise buildings. London's skyscrapers, such as [30 St Mary Axe](/wiki/30_St_Mary_Axe "30 St Mary Axe") (dubbed "The Gherkin"), [Tower 42](/wiki/Tower_42 "Tower 42"), the [Broadgate Tower](/wiki/Broadgate_Tower "Broadgate Tower") and [One Canada Square](/wiki/One_Canada_Square "One Canada Square"), are mostly in the two financial districts, the City of London and [Canary Wharf](/wiki/Canary_Wharf "Canary Wharf"). High-rise development is restricted at certain sites if it would obstruct [protected views](/wiki/Protected_view "Protected view") of [St Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral") and other historic buildings.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-Protected-189)^ This protective policy, known as 'St Paul's Heights', has been in operation by the City of London since 1937.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-Protected-189)^ Nevertheless, there are [a number of tall skyscrapers](/wiki/Tall_buildings_in_London "Tall buildings in London") in central London, including the 95-storey [Shard London Bridge](/wiki/Shard_London_Bridge "Shard London Bridge"), the [tallest building in the United Kingdom](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_United_Kingdom "List of tallest buildings in the United Kingdom") and Western Europe.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}

Other notable modern buildings include [The Scalpel](/wiki/The_Scalpel "The Scalpel"), [20 Fenchurch Street](/wiki/20_Fenchurch_Street "20 Fenchurch Street") (dubbed 'The Walkie-Talkie'), the former [City Hall](/wiki/City_Hall,_London_(Southwark) "City Hall, London (Southwark)") in [Southwark](/wiki/Southwark "Southwark"), the [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco") [BBC Broadcasting House](/wiki/BBC_Broadcasting_House "BBC Broadcasting House") plus the [Postmodernist](/wiki/Postmodernism "Postmodernism") [British Library](/wiki/British_Library "British Library") in [Somers Town](/wiki/Somers_Town,_London "Somers Town, London")/[Kings Cross](/wiki/Kings_Cross,_London "Kings Cross, London") and [No 1 Poultry](/wiki/No_1_Poultry "No 1 Poultry") by [James Stirling](/wiki/James_Stirling_(architect) "James Stirling (architect)"). The [BT Tower](/wiki/BT_Tower "BT Tower") stands at 620 feet (189 m) and has a 360 degree coloured LED screen near the top. What was formerly the [Millennium Dome](/wiki/Millennium_Dome "Millennium Dome"), by the Thames to the east of Canary Wharf, is now an entertainment venue called [the O~2~ Arena](/wiki/The_O2_Arena "The O2 Arena").^[\[183\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}

### Natural history {#Natural_history}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg/220px-Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg)](/wiki/File:Owl_on_a_phone_box,_Shepherd_Market.jpg) Owl decoy on top of a [red telephone box](/wiki/Red_telephone_box "Red telephone box") in [Shepherd Market](/wiki/Shepherd_Market "Shepherd Market") in [Mayfair](/wiki/Mayfair "Mayfair") as a deterrent to pigeons; there are an estimated 3 million pigeons in London.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-192)^

The [London Natural History Society](/wiki/London_Natural_History_Society "London Natural History Society") suggests that London is "one of the World's Greenest Cities" with more than 40% green space or open water. They indicate that 2000 species of flowering plant have been found growing there and that the [tidal Thames](/wiki/Tideway "Tideway") supports 120 species of fish.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-193)^ They state that over 60 species of bird nest in [central London](/wiki/Central_London "Central London") and that their members have recorded 47 species of butterfly, 1,173 moths and more than 270 kinds of spider around London. London's [wetland](/wiki/Wetland "Wetland") areas support nationally important populations of many water birds. London has 38 [Sites of Special Scientific Interest](/wiki/List_of_Sites_of_Special_Scientific_Interest_in_Greater_London "List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London") (SSSIs), two [national nature reserves](/wiki/National_nature_reserve_(United_Kingdom) "National nature reserve (United Kingdom)") and 76 [local nature reserves](/wiki/List_of_local_nature_reserves_in_Greater_London "List of local nature reserves in Greater London").^[\[186\]](#cite_note-194)^{#cite_ref-194}

[Amphibians](/wiki/Amphibians "Amphibians") are common in the capital, including [smooth newts](/wiki/Smooth_newt "Smooth newt") living by the [Tate Modern](/wiki/Tate_Modern "Tate Modern"), and [common frogs](/wiki/Common_frog "Common frog"), [common toads](/wiki/Common_toad "Common toad"), [palmate newts](/wiki/Palmate_newt "Palmate newt"), and [great crested newts](/wiki/Great_crested_newt "Great crested newt"). On the other hand, native reptiles such as [slowworms](/wiki/Slowworm "Slowworm"), [common lizards](/wiki/Common_lizard "Common lizard"), [barred grass snakes](/wiki/Barred_grass_snake "Barred grass snake"), and [adders](/wiki/Vipera_berus "Vipera berus"), are mostly only seen in [Outer London](/wiki/Outer_London "Outer London").^[\[187\]](#cite_note-195)^{#cite_ref-195}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg) A fox on Ayres Street, [Southwark](/wiki/Southwark "Southwark"), [South London](/wiki/South_London "South London")

Among other inhabitants of London are 10,000 [red foxes](/wiki/Red_fox "Red fox"), so that there are now 16 foxes for every square mile (6 per square km) of London. Other mammals found in [Greater London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London") are [hedgehog](/wiki/European_hedgehog "European hedgehog"), [brown rat](/wiki/Brown_rat "Brown rat"), mice, [rabbit](/wiki/European_rabbit "European rabbit"), [shrew](/wiki/Shrew "Shrew"), [vole](/wiki/Vole "Vole"), and [grey squirrel](/wiki/Grey_squirrel "Grey squirrel").^[\[188\]](#cite_note-196)^ In wilder areas of Outer London, such as [Epping Forest](/wiki/Epping_Forest "Epping Forest"), a wide variety of mammals are found, including [European hare](/wiki/European_hare "European hare"), [badger](/wiki/European_badger "European badger"), [field](/wiki/Field_vole "Field vole"), [bank](/wiki/Bank_vole "Bank vole") and [water vole](/wiki/European_water_vole "European water vole"), [wood mouse](/wiki/Wood_mouse "Wood mouse"), [yellow-necked mouse](/wiki/Yellow-necked_mouse "Yellow-necked mouse"), [mole](/wiki/European_mole "European mole"), shrew, and [weasel](/wiki/Least_weasel "Least weasel"), in addition to red fox, grey squirrel and hedgehog. A dead [otter](/wiki/Eurasian_otter "Eurasian otter") was found at The Highway, in [Wapping](/wiki/Wapping "Wapping"), about 1 mile (1.6 km) from the [Tower Bridge](/wiki/Tower_Bridge "Tower Bridge"), which would suggest that they have begun to move back after being absent a hundred years from the city.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-197)^ Ten of England's eighteen species of bats have been recorded in Epping Forest: [soprano](/wiki/Soprano_pipistrelle "Soprano pipistrelle"), [Nathusius'](/wiki/Nathusius%27_pipistrelle "Nathusius' pipistrelle") and [common pipistrelles](/wiki/Common_pipistrelle "Common pipistrelle"), [common noctule](/wiki/Common_noctule "Common noctule"), [serotine](/wiki/Serotine "Serotine"), [barbastelle](/wiki/Barbastelle "Barbastelle"), [Daubenton's](/wiki/Daubenton%27s_bat "Daubenton's bat"), [brown long-eared](/wiki/Brown_long-eared_bat "Brown long-eared bat"), [Natterer's](/wiki/Natterer%27s_bat "Natterer's bat"), and [Leisler's](/wiki/Leisler%27s_bat "Leisler's bat").^[\[190\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}

Herds of [red](/wiki/Red_deer "Red deer") and [fallow deer](/wiki/Fallow_deer "Fallow deer") roam freely within much of [Richmond](/wiki/Richmond_Park "Richmond Park") and [Bushy Park](/wiki/Bushy_Park "Bushy Park"). A cull takes place each November and February to ensure numbers can be sustained.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-Deer_cull_begins-199)^ Epping Forest is also known for its fallow deer, which can frequently be seen in herds to the north of the Forest. A rare population of [melanistic](/wiki/Melanistic "Melanistic"), black fallow deer is also maintained at the Deer Sanctuary near [Theydon Bois](/wiki/Theydon_Bois "Theydon Bois"). [Muntjac deer](/wiki/Reeve%27s_muntjac "Reeve's muntjac") are also found in the forest. While Londoners are accustomed to wildlife such as birds and foxes sharing the city, more recently urban deer have started becoming a regular feature, and whole herds of fallow deer come into residential areas at night to take advantage of London's green spaces.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-200)^{#cite_ref-200}
