London's continuous urban area extends beyond Greater London and numbered 9,787,426 people in 2011,^[\[3\]](#cite_note-urbanpopulation-4)^ while its wider [metropolitan area](/wiki/London_metropolitan_area "London metropolitan area") had a population of 12--14 million, depending on the definition used.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-metro_area_1-202)^ According to [Eurostat](/wiki/Eurostat "Eurostat"), London is the second [most populous](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe "List of metropolitan areas in Europe") metropolitan area in Europe. A net 726,000 immigrants arrived there in the period 1991--2001.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-Immigration-203)^{#cite_ref-Immigration_203-0}

The region covers 610 square miles (1,579 km^2^), giving a population density of 13,410 inhabitants per square mile (5,177/km^2^)^[\[143\]](#cite_note-Metrop-150)^ more than ten times that of any other [British region](/wiki/ITL_(UK) "ITL (UK)").^[\[196\]](#cite_note-london_087-204)^ In population terms, London is the 19th [largest city](/wiki/World%27s_largest_cities "World's largest cities") and the 18th [largest metropolitan region](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population "List of metropolitan areas by population").^[\[197\]](#cite_note-Billionaires-205)^{#cite_ref-Billionaires_205-0}

In tenure, 23.1% socially rent within London, 46.8% either own their house outright or with a mortgage or loan and 30% privately rent at the 2021 census.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-206)^ Many Londoner's work from home, 42.9% did so at the 2021 census while 20.6% drive a car to work. The biggest decrease in method of transportation was seen within those who take the train and underground, declining from 22.6% in 2011 to 9.6% in 2021.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-207)^ In qualifications, 46.7% of London had census classified Level 4 qualifications or higher, which is predominately university degrees. 16.2% had no qualifications at all.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-208)^{#cite_ref-208}  

### Age structure and median age {#Age_structure_and_median_age}

London's median age is one of the youngest regions in the UK. It was recorded in 2018 that London's residents were 36.5 years old, which was younger than the UK median of 40.3.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-:1-209)^{#cite_ref-:1_209-0}

Children younger than 14 constituted 20.6% of the population in Outer London in 2018, and 18% in Inner London. The 15--24 age group was 11.1% in Outer and 10.2% in Inner London, those aged 25--44 years 30.6% in Outer London and 39.7% in Inner London, those aged 45--64 years 24% and 20.7% in Outer and Inner London respectively. Those aged 65 and over are 13.6% in Outer London, but only 9.3% in Inner London.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-:1-209)^{#cite_ref-:1_209-1}  

### Country of birth {#Country_of_birth}

The 2021 census recorded that 3,575,739 people or 40.6% of London's population were [foreign-born](/wiki/Foreign-born_population_of_the_United_Kingdom "Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom"),^[\[202\]](#cite_note-Census2021-210)^ making it among the cities with the [largest immigrant population](/wiki/Foreign_born#Cities_with_largest_foreign_born_populations "Foreign born") in terms of absolute numbers and a growth of roughly 3 million since 1971 when the foreign born population was 668,373.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-211)^ 13% of the total population were Asian born (32.1% of the total foreign born population), 7.1% are African born (17.5%), 15.5% are Other European born (38.2%), and 4.2% were born in the Americas and Caribbean (10.3%).^[\[204\]](#cite_note-:3-212)^ The 5 largest single countries of origin were respectively India, Romania, Poland, Bangladesh and Pakistan.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-:3-212)^{#cite_ref-:3_212-1}

About 56.8% of children born in London in 2021 were born to a mother who was born abroad.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-:4-213)^ This trend has been increasing in the past two decades when foreign born mothers made up 43.3% of births in 2001 in London, becoming the majority in the middle of the 2000s by 2006 comprising 52.5%.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-:4-213)^{#cite_ref-:4_213-1}

A large degree of the foreign born population who were present at the 2021 census had arrived relatively recently. Of the total population, those that arrived between the years of 2011 and 2021 account for 16.6% of London.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-:6-214)^ Those who arrived between 2001 and 2010 are 10.4%, between 1991 and 2001, 5.7%, and prior to 1990, 7.3%.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-:6-214)^{#cite_ref-:6_214-1}  

### Ethnic groups {#Ethnic_groups}

Main article: [Ethnic groups in London](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_London "Ethnic groups in London")

According to the [Office for National Statistics](/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics "Office for National Statistics"), based on the 2021 census, 53.8% of the 8,173,941 inhabitants of London were [White](/wiki/White_people "White people"), with 36.8% [White British](/wiki/White_British "White British"), 1.8% [White Irish](/wiki/Irish_migration_to_Great_Britain "Irish migration to Great Britain"), 0.1% [Gypsy](/wiki/Gypsy_(term) "Gypsy (term)")/[Irish Traveller](/wiki/Irish_traveller "Irish traveller"), 0.4 Roma and 14.7% classified as [Other White](/wiki/Other_White "Other White").^[\[207\]](#cite_note-:5-215)^ Meanwhile, 22.2% of Londoners were of [Asian](/wiki/British_Asian "British Asian") or mixed-Asian descent, with 20.8% being of full Asian descents and 1.4% being of mixed-Asian heritage. [Indians](/wiki/British_Indian "British Indian") accounted for 7.5% of the population, followed by [Bangladeshis](/wiki/British_Bangladeshi "British Bangladeshi") and [Pakistanis](/wiki/British_Pakistanis "British Pakistanis") at 3.7% and 3.3% respectively. [Chinese](/wiki/British_Chinese "British Chinese") people accounted for 1.7%, and [Arabs](/wiki/British_Arabs "British Arabs") for 1.6%. A further 4.6% were classified as "Other Asian".^[\[207\]](#cite_note-:5-215)^ 15.9% of London's population were of [Black](/wiki/Black_British "Black British") or mixed-Black descent. 13.5% were of full Black descent, with persons of mixed-Black heritage comprising 2.4%. [Black Africans](/wiki/Black_British "Black British") accounted for 7.9% of London's population; 3.9% identified as [Black Caribbean](/wiki/British_African-Caribbean_community "British African-Caribbean community"), and 1.7% as "Other Black". 5.7% were of [mixed race](/wiki/Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category) "Mixed (United Kingdom ethnicity category)").^[\[207\]](#cite_note-:5-215)^ This ethnic structure has changed considerably since the 1960s. Estimates for 1961 put the total non-White ethnic minority population at 179,109 comprising 2.3% of the population at the time,^[\[208\]](#cite_note-216)^^[\[209\]](#cite_note-217)^ having risen since then to 1,346,119 and 20.2% in 1991^[\[210\]](#cite_note-218)^ and 4,068,553 and 46.2% in 2021.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-:7-219)^ Of those of a White British background, estimates for 1971 put the population at 6,500,000 and 87% of the total population,^[\[212\]](#cite_note-220)^ of since fell to 3,239,281 and 36.8% in 2021.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-:7-219)^{#cite_ref-:7_219-1}

As of 2021, the majority of London's school pupils come from ethnic minority backgrounds. 23.9% were White British, 14% Other White, 23.2% Asian, 17.9% Black, 11.3% Mixed, 6.3% Other and 2.3% unclassified.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-221)^ Altogether at the 2021 census, of London's 1,695,741 population aged 0 to 15, 42% were White in total, splitting it down into 30.9% who were White British, 0.5% Irish, 10.6% Other White, 23% Asian, 16.4% Black, 12% Mixed and 6.6% another ethnic group.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-222)^{#cite_ref-222}  

### Languages {#Languages}

In January 2005, a survey of London's ethnic and religious diversity claimed that more than 300 languages were spoken in London and more than 50 non-indigenous communities had populations of more than 10,000.^[\[215\]](#cite_note-london_090-223)^ At the 2021 census, 78.4% of Londoners spoke English as their first language.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-:8-224)^ The 5 biggest languages outside of English were Romanian, Spanish, Polish, Bengali, and Portuguese.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-:8-224)^{#cite_ref-:8_224-1}

According to the [2021 Census](/wiki/2021_United_Kingdom_census "2021 United Kingdom census"), the largest religious groupings were [Christians](/wiki/British_Christianity "British Christianity") (40.66%), followed by those of no religion (20.7%), [Muslims](/wiki/Islam_in_London "Islam in London") (15%), no response (8.5%), [Hindus](/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_Kingdom "Hinduism in the United Kingdom") (5.15%), Jews (1.65%), [Sikhs](/wiki/Sikhism_in_the_United_Kingdom "Sikhism in the United Kingdom") (1.64%), [Buddhists](/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_United_Kingdom "Buddhism in the United Kingdom") (1.0%) and other (0.8%).^[\[217\]](#cite_note-census2021-225)^^[\[218\]](#cite_note-226)^{#cite_ref-226}

London has traditionally been [Christian](/wiki/Christian "Christian"), and has a [large number of churches](/wiki/List_of_churches_in_London "List of churches in London"), particularly in the City of London. The well-known [St Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral") in the City and [Southwark Cathedral](/wiki/Southwark_Cathedral "Southwark Cathedral") south of the river are [Anglican](/wiki/Anglicanism "Anglicanism") administrative centres,^[\[219\]](#cite_note-london_096-227)^ while the [Archbishop of Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of Canterbury"), principal bishop of the [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England") and worldwide [Anglican Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican Communion"), has his main residence at [Lambeth Palace](/wiki/Lambeth_Palace "Lambeth Palace") in the [London Borough of Lambeth](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Lambeth "London Borough of Lambeth").^[\[220\]](#cite_note-london_097-228)^{#cite_ref-london_097_228-0}

Important national and royal ceremonies are shared between [St Paul's](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral") and [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey").^[\[221\]](#cite_note-london_098-229)^ The Abbey is not to be confused with nearby [Westminster Cathedral](/wiki/Westminster_Cathedral "Westminster Cathedral"), the largest [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") cathedral in [England and Wales](/wiki/England_and_Wales "England and Wales").^[\[222\]](#cite_note-london_099-230)^ Despite the prevalence of Anglican churches, observance is low within the denomination. Anglican Church attendance continues a long, steady decline, according to Church of England statistics.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-london_100-231)^{#cite_ref-london_100_231-0}

Notable mosques include the [East London Mosque](/wiki/East_London_Mosque "East London Mosque") in Tower Hamlets, which is allowed to give the Islamic call to prayer through loudspeakers, the [London Central Mosque](/wiki/London_Central_Mosque "London Central Mosque") on the edge of [Regent's Park](/wiki/Regent%27s_Park "Regent's Park")^[\[224\]](#cite_note-london_101-232)^ and the [Baitul Futuh](/wiki/Baitul_Futuh "Baitul Futuh") of the [Ahmadiyya Muslim Community](/wiki/Ahmadiyya_Muslim_Community "Ahmadiyya Muslim Community"). After the oil boom, increasing numbers of wealthy [Middle-Eastern](/wiki/Middle-East "Middle-East") Arab Muslims based themselves around [Mayfair](/wiki/Mayfair "Mayfair"), Kensington and [Knightsbridge](/wiki/Knightsbridge "Knightsbridge") in West London.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-233)^^[\[226\]](#cite_note-234)^^[\[227\]](#cite_note-london_102-235)^ There are large [Bengali Muslim](/wiki/Bengali_Muslim "Bengali Muslim") communities in the eastern boroughs of [Tower Hamlets](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Tower_Hamlets "London Borough of Tower Hamlets") and [Newham](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Newham "London Borough of Newham").^[\[228\]](#cite_note-236)^{#cite_ref-236}

Large Hindu communities are found in the north-western boroughs of [Harrow](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Harrow "London Borough of Harrow") and [Brent](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Brent "London Borough of Brent"), the latter hosting what was until 2006^[\[229\]](#cite_note-237)^ Europe's largest [Hindu temple](/wiki/Hindu_temple "Hindu temple"), [Neasden Temple](/wiki/Neasden_Temple "Neasden Temple").^[\[230\]](#cite_note-london_103-238)^ London is home to 44 Hindu temples, including the [BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London](/wiki/BAPS_Shri_Swaminarayan_Mandir_London "BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London"). There are Sikh communities in East and West London, particularly in Southall, home to one of the largest Sikh populations and the largest Sikh temple outside India.^[\[231\]](#cite_note-london_104-239)^{#cite_ref-london_104_239-0}

The majority of [British Jews](/wiki/British_Jews "British Jews") live in London, with notable Jewish communities in [Stamford Hill](/wiki/Stamford_Hill "Stamford Hill"), [Stanmore](/wiki/Stanmore "Stanmore"), [Golders Green](/wiki/Golders_Green "Golders Green"), [Finchley](/wiki/Finchley "Finchley"), [Hampstead](/wiki/Hampstead "Hampstead"), [Hendon](/wiki/Hendon "Hendon"), and [Edgware](/wiki/Edgware "Edgware"), all in [North London](/wiki/North_London "North London"). [Bevis Marks Synagogue](/wiki/Bevis_Marks_Synagogue "Bevis Marks Synagogue") in the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London") is affiliated to London's historic [Sephardic](/wiki/Sephardic "Sephardic") Jewish community. It is the only synagogue in Europe to have held regular services continually for over 300 years. [Stanmore and Canons Park Synagogue](/wiki/Stanmore_and_Canons_Park_Synagogue "Stanmore and Canons Park Synagogue") has the largest membership of any Orthodox synagogue in Europe.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-london_106-240)^ The [London Jewish Forum](/wiki/London_Jewish_Forum "London Jewish Forum") was set up in 2006 in response to the growing significance of devolved London Government.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-london_107-241)^{#cite_ref-london_107_241-0}  

### Accents {#Accents}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg/170px-St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg) Traditionally, anyone born within earshot of the bells of [St Mary-le-Bow](/wiki/St_Mary-le-Bow "St Mary-le-Bow") church was considered to be a true [Cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney").^[\[234\]](#cite_note-242)^

[Cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney") is an accent heard across London, mainly spoken by [working-class](/wiki/Working_class "Working class") and [lower-middle-class](/wiki/Lower_middle_class "Lower middle class") Londoners. It is mainly attributed to the East End and wider East London, having originated there in the 18th century, although it has been suggested that the Cockney style of speech is much older.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-243)^ Some features of Cockney include [*Th*-fronting](/wiki/Th-fronting "Th-fronting") (pronouncing "th" as "f"), "th" inside a word is pronounced with a "v", [*H*-dropping](/wiki/H-dropping "H-dropping"), and, like most English accents, a Cockney accent [drops the "r"](/wiki/Rhoticity_in_English "Rhoticity in English") after a vowel.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-244)^ John Camden Hotten, in his *Slang Dictionary* of 1859, makes reference to Cockney "use of a peculiar slang language" ([Cockney rhyming slang](/wiki/Rhyming_slang "Rhyming slang")) when describing the [costermongers](/wiki/Costermonger "Costermonger") of the East End. Since the start of the 21st century the extreme form of the Cockney dialect is less common in parts of the East End itself, with modern strongholds including other parts of London and suburbs in the [home counties](/wiki/Home_counties "Home counties").^[\[237\]](#cite_note-245)^ This is particularly pronounced in areas like Romford (in the London Borough of Havering) and [Southend](/wiki/Southend-on-Sea "Southend-on-Sea") (in Essex), which have received significant inflows of older East End residents in recent decades.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-246)^{#cite_ref-246}

[Estuary English](/wiki/Estuary_English "Estuary English") is an intermediate accent between Cockney and [Received Pronunciation](/wiki/Received_Pronunciation "Received Pronunciation").^[\[239\]](#cite_note-247)^ It is widely spoken by people of all classes.^[\[240\]](#cite_note-248)^{#cite_ref-248}

[Multicultural London English](/wiki/Multicultural_London_English "Multicultural London English") (MLE) is a [multiethnolect](/wiki/Multiethnolect "Multiethnolect") becoming increasingly common in multicultural areas amongst young, working-class people from diverse backgrounds. It is a fusion of an array of ethnic accents, in particular Afro-Caribbean and South Asian, with a significant Cockney influence.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-249)^{#cite_ref-249}

[Received Pronunciation](/wiki/Received_Pronunciation "Received Pronunciation") (RP) is the accent traditionally regarded as the standard for [British English](/wiki/British_English "British English").^[\[242\]](#cite_note-250)^ It has no specific geographical correlate,^[\[243\]](#cite_note-251)^ although it is also traditionally defined as the standard speech used in London and south-eastern England.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-252)^ It is mainly spoken by [upper-class](/wiki/Upper_class "Upper class") and [upper-middle class](/wiki/Upper_middle_class "Upper middle class") Londoners.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-253)^ Standard Southern British English (SSBE) has been considered as an evolution of RP that is now common and widely spoken in London and the south-east of England by a wide variety of people, but is distinct from Estuary English and MLE.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-254)^{#cite_ref-254}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

Main article: [Economy of London](/wiki/Economy_of_London "Economy of London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg/220px-City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg)](/wiki/File:City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg) The [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London"), one of the largest [financial centres](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") in the world

London's [gross regional product](/wiki/Gross_regional_product "Gross regional product") in 2019 was £503 billion, around a quarter of [UK GDP](/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom "Economy of the United Kingdom").^[\[247\]](#cite_note-255)^ London has five major business districts: the city, Westminster, Canary Wharf, Camden \& Islington, and Lambeth \& Southwark. One way to get an idea of their relative importance is to look at relative amounts of office space: Greater London had 27 million m^2^ of office space in 2001, and the City contains the most space, with 8 million m^2^ of office space. London has some of the highest real estate prices in the world.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-256)^{#cite_ref-256}  

### City of London {#City_of_London}

London's finance industry is based in the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London") and [Canary Wharf](/wiki/Canary_Wharf "Canary Wharf"), the two major [business districts](/wiki/Central_business_district "Central business district"). London took over as a major financial centre shortly after 1795 when the Dutch Republic collapsed before the Napoleonic armies. This caused many bankers established in [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam") (e.g. Hope, Baring I'm), to move to London. Also, London's market-centred system (as opposed to the bank-centred one in Amsterdam) grew more dominant in the 18th century.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-Finance_Hub-81)^ The London financial elite was strengthened by a strong Jewish community from all over Europe capable of mastering the most sophisticated financial tools of the time.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-auto2-85)^ This economic strength of the city was attributed to its diversity.^[\[249\]](#cite_note-257)^^[\[250\]](#cite_note-258)^{#cite_ref-258}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/220px-Paternoster_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:Paternoster_Square.jpg) The [London Stock Exchange](/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange "London Stock Exchange") at [Paternoster Square](/wiki/Paternoster_Square "Paternoster Square") and [Temple Bar](/wiki/Temple_Bar,_London "Temple Bar, London") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/220px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg)](/wiki/File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg) The [Bank of England](/wiki/Bank_of_England "Bank of England"), established in 1694, is the model on which most modern central banks are based.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-259)^

By the mid-19th century, London was the leading financial centre, and at the end of the century over half the world's trade was financed in British currency.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-260)^ As of 2023^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&action=edit)^, London ranks second in the world rankings on the [Global Financial Centres Index](/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index "Global Financial Centres Index") (GFCI),^[\[253\]](#cite_note-261)^ and it ranked second in A.T. Kearney's 2018 Global Cities Index.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-262)^{#cite_ref-262}

London's largest industry is finance, and its [financial exports](/wiki/Financial_export "Financial export") make it a large contributor to the UK's [balance of payments](/wiki/Balance_of_payments "Balance of payments"). Notwithstanding a post-[Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit") exodus of stock listings from the [London Stock Exchange](/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange "London Stock Exchange"),^[\[18\]](#cite_note-LSEExodusToNewYork-24)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-LSEExodus-25)^ London is still one of Europe's most economically powerful cities,^[\[20\]](#cite_note-London.gov.uk-26)^ and it remains one of the major financial centres of the world. It is the world's biggest currency trading centre, accounting for some 37% of the $5.1 trillion average daily volume, according to the BIS.^[\[255\]](#cite_note-263)^ Over 85% (3.2 million) of the employed population of greater London works in the services industries. Because of its prominent global role, London's economy had been affected by the [financial crisis of 2007--2008](/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008 "Financial crisis of 2007–2008"). However, by 2010 the city had recovered, put in place new regulatory powers, proceeded to regain lost ground and re-established London's economic dominance.^[\[256\]](#cite_note-264)^ Along with [professional services](/wiki/Professional_services "Professional services") headquarters, the City of London is home to the [Bank of England](/wiki/Bank_of_England "Bank of England"), London Stock Exchange, and [Lloyd's of London](/wiki/Lloyd%27s_of_London "Lloyd's of London") insurance market.^[\[257\]](#cite_note-265)^ Founded in 1690, [Barclays](/wiki/Barclays "Barclays"), whose [branch in Enfield](/wiki/Barclays_Bank,_Enfield "Barclays Bank, Enfield"), north London installed the first [cash machine](/wiki/Automated_teller_machine "Automated teller machine") (ATM) in 1967, is one of the [oldest banks in continuous operation](/wiki/List_of_oldest_banks_in_continuous_operation "List of oldest banks in continuous operation").^[\[258\]](#cite_note-266)^{#cite_ref-266}

Over half the UK's top 100 listed companies (the [FTSE 100](/wiki/FTSE_100 "FTSE 100")) and over 100 of Europe's 500 largest companies have their headquarters in central London. Over 70% of the FTSE 100 are within London's metropolitan area, and 75% of [Fortune 500](/wiki/Fortune_500 "Fortune 500") companies have offices in London.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-london_113-267)^ In a 1992 report commissioned by the London Stock Exchange, Sir [Adrian Cadbury](/wiki/Adrian_Cadbury "Adrian Cadbury"), chairman of his family's confectionery company [Cadbury](/wiki/Cadbury "Cadbury"), produced the [Cadbury Report](/wiki/Cadbury_Report "Cadbury Report"), a code of best practice which served as a basis for reform of [corporate governance](/wiki/Corporate_governance "Corporate governance") around the world.^[\[260\]](#cite_note-268)^{#cite_ref-268}  

### Media and technology {#Media_and_technology}

Main article: [Media in London](/wiki/Media_in_London "Media in London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg/170px-Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg)](/wiki/File:Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg) [Broadcasting House](/wiki/Broadcasting_House "Broadcasting House"), headquarters of the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC")

Media companies are concentrated in London, and the media distribution industry is London's second most competitive sector.^[\[261\]](#cite_note-london_114-269)^ The [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"), the world's oldest national broadcaster, is a significant employer, while other broadcasters, including [ITV](/wiki/ITV_(TV_network) "ITV (TV network)"), [Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4"), [Channel 5](/wiki/Channel_5_(UK) "Channel 5 (UK)"), and [Sky](/wiki/Sky_UK "Sky UK"), also have headquarters around the city. Many [national newspapers](/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_United_Kingdom "List of newspapers in the United Kingdom"), including *[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")* , founded in 1785, are edited in London; the term [Fleet Street](/wiki/Fleet_Street "Fleet Street") (where most national newspapers operated) remains a [metonym](/wiki/Metonym "Metonym") for the British national press.^[\[262\]](#cite_note-270)^ The communications company [WPP](/wiki/WPP_plc "WPP plc") is the world's largest advertising agency.^[\[263\]](#cite_note-271)^{#cite_ref-271}

A large number of technology companies are based in London, notably in [East London Tech City](/wiki/East_London_Tech_City "East London Tech City"), also known as Silicon Roundabout. In 2014 the city was among the first to receive a [geoTLD](/wiki/GeoTLD "GeoTLD").^[\[264\]](#cite_note-272)^ In February 2014 London was ranked as the European City of the Future in the 2014/15 list by *[fDi Intelligence](/wiki/FDi_Intelligence "FDi Intelligence")* .^[\[265\]](#cite_note-273)^ A museum in [Bletchley Park](/wiki/Bletchley_Park "Bletchley Park"), where [Alan Turing](/wiki/Alan_Turing "Alan Turing") was based during World War II, is in [Bletchley](/wiki/Bletchley "Bletchley"), 40 miles (64 km) north of central London, as is [The National Museum of Computing](/wiki/The_National_Museum_of_Computing "The National Museum of Computing").^[\[266\]](#cite_note-274)^{#cite_ref-274}

The gas and electricity distribution networks that manage and operate the towers, cables and pressure systems that deliver energy to consumers across the city are managed by [National Grid plc](/wiki/National_Grid_plc "National Grid plc"), [SGN](/wiki/SGN_(company) "SGN (company)")^[\[267\]](#cite_note-275)^ and [UK Power Networks](/wiki/UK_Power_Networks "UK Power Networks").^[\[268\]](#cite_note-276)^{#cite_ref-276}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

Main article: [Tourism in London](/wiki/Tourism_in_London "Tourism in London")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/200px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:British_Museum_from_NE_2_(cropped).JPG)  
The [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/200px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG)](/wiki/File:Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-07,_DD_036.JPG)  
The [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery "National Gallery")

London is one of the leading tourist destinations in the world. It is also the top city in the world by visitor cross-border spending, estimated at US$20.23 billion in 2015.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-277)^ Tourism is one of London's prime industries, employing 700,000 full-time workers in 2016, and contributes £36 billion a year to the economy.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-278)^ The city accounts for 54% of all inbound visitor spending in the UK.^[\[271\]](#cite_note-279)^{#cite_ref-279}

In 2015, the top ten most-visited attractions in the UK were all in London (shown with visits per venue):^[\[272\]](#cite_note-280)^{#cite_ref-280}

1. [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum"): 6,820,686
2. [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery "National Gallery"): 5,908,254
3. [Natural History Museum](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London "Natural History Museum, London") (South Kensington): 5,284,023
4. [Southbank Centre](/wiki/Southbank_Centre "Southbank Centre"): 5,102,883
5. [Tate Modern](/wiki/Tate_Modern "Tate Modern"): 4,712,581
6. [Victoria and Albert Museum](/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum "Victoria and Albert Museum") (South Kensington): 3,432,325
7. [Science Museum](/wiki/Science_Museum,_London "Science Museum, London"): 3,356,212
8. [Somerset House](/wiki/Somerset_House "Somerset House"): 3,235,104
9. [Tower of London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London"): 2,785,249
10. [National Portrait Gallery](/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery,_London "National Portrait Gallery, London"): 2,145,486

The number of hotel rooms in London in 2023 stood at 155,700 and is expected to grow to 183,600 rooms, the most of any city outside China.^[\[273\]](#cite_note-281)^ Luxury hotels in London include [the Savoy](/wiki/Savoy_Hotel "Savoy Hotel") (opened in 1889), [Claridge's](/wiki/Claridge%27s "Claridge's") (opened in 1812 and rebuilt in 1898), [the Ritz](/wiki/The_Ritz_Hotel,_London "The Ritz Hotel, London") (opened in 1906) and [the Dorchester](/wiki/The_Dorchester "The Dorchester") (opened in 1931), while budget hotel chains include [Premier Inn](/wiki/Premier_Inn "Premier Inn") and [Travelodge](/wiki/Travelodge "Travelodge").^[\[274\]](#cite_note-282)^{#cite_ref-282}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

Main articles: [Transport in London](/wiki/Transport_in_London "Transport in London") and [Infrastructure in London](/wiki/Infrastructure_in_London "Infrastructure in London")

Transport is one of the four main areas of policy administered by the [Mayor of London](/wiki/Mayor_of_London "Mayor of London"),^[\[275\]](#cite_note-london_121-283)^ but the mayor's financial control does not extend to the longer-distance rail network that enters London. In 2007, the Mayor of London assumed responsibility for some local lines, which now form the [London Overground](/wiki/London_Overground "London Overground") network, adding to the existing responsibility for the London Underground, trams and buses. The public transport network is administered by [Transport for London](/wiki/Transport_for_London "Transport for London") (TfL).^[\[111\]](#cite_note-london_goverance-118)^{#cite_ref-london_goverance_118-1}

The lines that formed the London Underground, as well as trams and buses, became part of an integrated transport system in 1933 when the [London Passenger Transport Board](/wiki/London_Passenger_Transport_Board "London Passenger Transport Board") or *[London Transport](/wiki/London_Transport_(brand) "London Transport (brand)")* was created. Transport for London is now the statutory corporation responsible for most aspects of the transport system in Greater London, and is run by a board and a commissioner appointed by the Mayor of London.^[\[276\]](#cite_note-284)^{#cite_ref-284}  

### Aviation {#Aviation}

Main article: [Airports of London](/wiki/Airports_of_London "Airports of London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/220px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg) [Heathrow Airport](/wiki/Heathrow_Airport "Heathrow Airport") is the busiest airport in Europe as well as the second busiest in the world for international passenger traffic ([Terminal 5](/wiki/Heathrow_Terminal_5 "Heathrow Terminal 5")C is pictured).

London is a major international air transport hub with the [busiest city airspace](/wiki/World%27s_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic "World's busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic") in the world.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Busiest_skies-30)^ Eight airports use the word *London* in their name, but most traffic passes through six of these. Additionally, [various other airports](/wiki/Airports_of_London "Airports of London") also serve London, catering primarily to [general aviation](/wiki/General_aviation "General aviation") flights.{#cite_ref-Busiest_skies_30-1}

* [Heathrow Airport](/wiki/Heathrow_Airport "Heathrow Airport"), in [Hillingdon](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Hillingdon "London Borough of Hillingdon"), West London, was for many years the [busiest airport](/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airport "World's busiest airport") in the world for international traffic, and is the major hub of the nation's flag carrier, [British Airways](/wiki/British_Airways "British Airways").^[\[277\]](#cite_note-london_135-285)^ In March 2008 its fifth terminal was opened.^[\[278\]](#cite_note-london_137-286)^{#cite_ref-london_137_286-0}
* [Gatwick Airport](/wiki/Gatwick_Airport "Gatwick Airport"), south of London in [West Sussex](/wiki/West_Sussex "West Sussex"), handles flights to more destinations than any other UK airport and is the main base of [easyJet](/wiki/EasyJet "EasyJet"), the UK's largest airline by number of passengers.^[\[279\]](#cite_note-287)^{#cite_ref-287}
* [London Stansted Airport](/wiki/London_Stansted_Airport "London Stansted Airport"), north-east of London in [Essex](/wiki/Essex "Essex"), has flights that serve the greatest number of European destinations of any UK airport and is the main base of [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair"), the world's largest international airline by number of international passengers.^[\[280\]](#cite_note-288)^{#cite_ref-288}
* [Luton Airport](/wiki/Luton_Airport "Luton Airport"), to the north of London in [Bedfordshire](/wiki/Bedfordshire "Bedfordshire"), is used by several budget airlines (especially easyJet and [Wizz Air](/wiki/Wizz_Air "Wizz Air")) for short-haul flights.^[\[281\]](#cite_note-289)^{#cite_ref-289}
* [London City Airport](/wiki/London_City_Airport "London City Airport"), the most central airport and the one with the shortest runway, in [Newham](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Newham "London Borough of Newham"), East London, is focused on business travellers, with a mixture of full-service short-haul scheduled flights and considerable [business jet](/wiki/Business_jet "Business jet") traffic.^[\[282\]](#cite_note-290)^{#cite_ref-290}
* [London Southend Airport](/wiki/London_Southend_Airport "London Southend Airport"), east of London in Essex, is a smaller, regional airport that caters for short-haul flights on a limited, though growing, number of airlines.^[\[283\]](#cite_note-291)^ In 2017, international passengers made up over 95% of the total at Southend, the highest proportion of any London airport.^[\[284\]](#cite_note-292)^{#cite_ref-292}

### Rail {#Rail}

#### Underground and DLR {#Underground_and_DLR}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/216px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg)](/wiki/File:Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg)  
The [London Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground"), opened in January 1863, is the world's oldest and third-longest [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") system  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg/216px-Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg)](/wiki/File:Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg)  
The [roundel symbol](/wiki/London_Underground#Roundel "London Underground") designed by [Edward Johnston](/wiki/Edward_Johnston "Edward Johnston") and trademarked in 1917

Opened in 1863, the [London Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground"), commonly referred to as the Tube or just the Underground, is the oldest and third longest [metro](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") system in the world.^[\[285\]](#cite_note-293)^^[\[286\]](#cite_note-294)^ The system serves [272 stations](/wiki/List_of_London_Underground_stations "List of London Underground stations"), and was formed from several private companies, including the world's first underground electric line, the [City and South London Railway](/wiki/City_and_South_London_Railway "City and South London Railway"), which opened in 1890.^[\[287\]](#cite_note-295)^{#cite_ref-295}

Over 4 million journeys are made every day on the Underground network, over 1 billion each year.^[\[288\]](#cite_note-london_124-296)^ An investment programme is attempting to reduce congestion and improve reliability, including £6.5 billion (€7.7 billion) spent before the [2012 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics").^[\[289\]](#cite_note-297)^ The [Docklands Light Railway (DLR)](/wiki/Docklands_Light_Railway "Docklands Light Railway"), which opened in 1987, is a second, more [local metro system](/wiki/Medium-capacity_rail_transport_system "Medium-capacity rail transport system") using smaller and lighter tram-type vehicles that serve the [Docklands](/wiki/London_Docklands "London Docklands"), [Greenwich](/wiki/Greenwich "Greenwich") and [Lewisham](/wiki/Lewisham "Lewisham").^[\[290\]](#cite_note-298)^{#cite_ref-298}  

#### Suburban {#Suburban}

There are [368 railway stations](/wiki/List_of_London_railway_stations "List of London railway stations") in the [London Travelcard Zones](/wiki/London_fare_zones "London fare zones") on an extensive above-ground suburban railway network. South London, particularly, has a high concentration of railways as it has fewer Underground lines. Most rail lines terminate around the centre of London, running into [eighteen terminal stations](/wiki/London_station_group "London station group"), with the exception of the [Thameslink](/wiki/Thameslink_(route) "Thameslink (route)") trains connecting [Bedford](/wiki/Bedford "Bedford") in the north and [Brighton](/wiki/Brighton "Brighton") in the south via [Luton](/wiki/London_Luton_Airport "London Luton Airport") and [Gatwick](/wiki/Gatwick_Airport "Gatwick Airport") airports.^[\[291\]](#cite_note-london_127-299)^ London has Britain's busiest station by number of passengers---[Waterloo](/wiki/London_Waterloo_station "London Waterloo station"), with over 184 million people using the interchange station complex (which includes [Waterloo East](/wiki/London_Waterloo_East_railway_station "London Waterloo East railway station") station) each year.^[\[292\]](#cite_note-300)^ [Clapham Junction](/wiki/Clapham_Junction_railway_station "Clapham Junction railway station") is one of Europe's busiest rail interchanges.^[\[293\]](#cite_note-301)^{#cite_ref-301}

With the need for more rail capacity, the [Elizabeth Line](/wiki/Elizabeth_line "Elizabeth line") (also known as Crossrail) opened in May 2022.^[\[294\]](#cite_note-302)^ It is a new railway line running east to west through London and into the [Home Counties](/wiki/Home_Counties "Home Counties") with a branch to Heathrow Airport.^[\[295\]](#cite_note-303)^ It was Europe's biggest construction project, with a £15 billion projected cost.^[\[296\]](#cite_note-304)^{#cite_ref-304}  

#### Inter-city and international {#Inter-city_and_international}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/220px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg) [St Pancras International](/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station "St Pancras railway station") is the main terminal for high-speed [Eurostar](/wiki/Eurostar "Eurostar") and [High Speed 1](/wiki/High_Speed_1 "High Speed 1") services, as well as commuter suburban Thameslink and inter-city [East Midlands Railway](/wiki/East_Midlands_Railway "East Midlands Railway") services.

London is the centre of the [National Rail](/wiki/National_Rail "National Rail") network, with 70% of rail journeys starting or ending in London.^[\[297\]](#cite_note-305)^ [King's Cross station](/wiki/London_King%27s_Cross_railway_station "London King's Cross railway station") and [Euston station](/wiki/Euston_railway_station "Euston railway station"), both in London, are the starting points of the [East Coast Main Line](/wiki/East_Coast_Main_Line "East Coast Main Line") and the [West Coast Main Line](/wiki/West_Coast_Main_Line "West Coast Main Line") -- the two main railway lines in Britain. Like suburban rail services, regional and inter-city trains depart from several termini around the city centre, directly linking London with most of Great Britain's major cities and towns.^[\[298\]](#cite_note-306)^ *[The Flying Scotsman](/wiki/Flying_Scotsman_(train) "Flying Scotsman (train)")* is an express passenger train service that has operated between London and Edinburgh since 1862; the world famous steam locomotive named after this service, [*Flying Scotsman*](/wiki/LNER_Class_A3_4472_Flying_Scotsman "LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman"), was the first locomotive to reach the officially authenticated speed of 100 miles per hour (161 km/h) in 1934.^[\[299\]](#cite_note-307)^{#cite_ref-307}

Some international railway services to [Continental Europe](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe") were operated during the 20th century as [boat trains](/wiki/Boat_train "Boat train"). The opening of the [Channel Tunnel](/wiki/Channel_Tunnel "Channel Tunnel") in 1994 connected London directly to the continental rail network, allowing [Eurostar](/wiki/Eurostar "Eurostar") services to begin. Since 2007, high-speed trains link [St. Pancras International](/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station "St Pancras railway station") with [Lille](/wiki/Lille "Lille"), [Calais](/wiki/Calais "Calais"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), [Disneyland Paris](/wiki/Disneyland_Paris "Disneyland Paris"), [Brussels](/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam") and other European tourist destinations via the [High Speed 1](/wiki/High_Speed_1 "High Speed 1") rail link and the Channel Tunnel.^[\[300\]](#cite_note-308)^ The first [high-speed domestic](/wiki/Southeastern_(train_operating_company) "Southeastern (train operating company)") trains started in June 2009, linking [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent") to London.^[\[301\]](#cite_note-Southeastern_Highspeed-309)^ There are plans for a [second high speed line](/wiki/High_Speed_2 "High Speed 2") linking London to the Midlands, North West England, and Yorkshire.^[\[302\]](#cite_note-310)^{#cite_ref-310}  

### Buses, coaches and trams {#Buses.2C_coaches_and_trams}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg/250px-LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg)](/wiki/File:LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg/138px-East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg)](/wiki/File:East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_(ALM_50B)_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg)  
The [New Routemaster](/wiki/New_Routemaster "New Routemaster") (left) is the spiritual successor to the [AEC Routemaster](/wiki/AEC_Routemaster "AEC Routemaster") (right). First appearing in 1947, the red double-decker bus is an emblematic symbol of London.

London's [bus network](/wiki/London_Buses "London Buses") runs 24 hours a day with about 9,300 vehicles, over 675 bus routes and about 19,000 bus stops.^[\[303\]](#cite_note-Buses-311)^ In 2019 the network had over 2 billion commuter trips per year.^[\[304\]](#cite_note-312)^ Since 2010 an average of £1.2 billion is taken in revenue each year.^[\[305\]](#cite_note-313)^ London has one of the largest wheelchair-accessible networks in the world^[\[306\]](#cite_note-london_131-314)^ and from the third quarter of 2007, became more accessible to hearing and visually impaired passengers as audio-visual announcements were introduced.^[\[307\]](#cite_note-315)^{#cite_ref-315}

An emblem of London, the red [double-decker bus](/wiki/Double-decker_bus "Double-decker bus") first appeared in the city in 1947 with the [AEC Regent III RT](/wiki/AEC_Regent_III_RT "AEC Regent III RT") (predecessor to the [AEC Routemaster](/wiki/AEC_Routemaster "AEC Routemaster")).^[\[308\]](#cite_note-316)^ London's coach hub is [Victoria Coach Station](/wiki/Victoria_Coach_Station "Victoria Coach Station"), opened in 1932. Nationalised in 1970 and then purchased by London Transport (now [Transport for London](/wiki/Transport_for_London "Transport for London")), Victoria Coach Station has over 14 million passengers a year and provides services across the UK and continental Europe.^[\[309\]](#cite_note-317)^{#cite_ref-317}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg/220px-Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg) [Tramlink](/wiki/Tramlink "Tramlink") tram at [Wimbledon station](/wiki/Wimbledon_station "Wimbledon station"), south-west London

There is a modern tram network serving South London, known as [Tramlink](/wiki/Tramlink "Tramlink"). It has 39 stops and four routes, and carried over 29 million people in 2017.^[\[310\]](#cite_note-318)^ Since June 2008, Transport for London has completely owned and operated Tramlink.^[\[311\]](#cite_note-319)^{#cite_ref-319}  

### Cable car {#Cable_car}

London's first and to date only cable car is the [London Cable Car](/wiki/London_Cable_Car "London Cable Car"), which opened in June 2012. The cable car crosses the Thames and links [Greenwich Peninsula](/wiki/Greenwich_Peninsula "Greenwich Peninsula") with the [Royal Docks](/wiki/Royal_Docks "Royal Docks") in the east of the city. It is able to carry up to 2,500 passengers per hour in each direction at peak times.^[\[312\]](#cite_note-320)^{#cite_ref-320}  

### Cycling {#Cycling}

Main article: [Cycling in London](/wiki/Cycling_in_London "Cycling in London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/220px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belgrave_Road,_Victoria,_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg) Santander Cycle Hire, near [Victoria](/wiki/Victoria,_London "Victoria, London") in Central London

In the Greater London Area, around 670,000 people use a bike every day,^[\[313\]](#cite_note-321)^ meaning around 7% of the total population of around 8.8 million use a bike on an average day.^[\[314\]](#cite_note-322)^ Cycling has become an increasingly popular way to get around London. The launch of a [bicycle hire scheme](/wiki/Bicycle-sharing_system "Bicycle-sharing system") in July 2010 was successful and generally well received.^[\[315\]](#cite_note-323)^{#cite_ref-323}  

### Port and river boats {#Port_and_river_boats}

The [Port of London](/wiki/Port_of_London "Port of London"), once the largest in the world, is now only the second-largest in the United Kingdom, handling 45 million tonnes of cargo each year as of 2009.^[\[316\]](#cite_note-handling-324)^ Most of this cargo passes through the [Port of Tilbury](/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury "Port of Tilbury"), outside the boundary of Greater London.^[\[316\]](#cite_note-handling-324)^{#cite_ref-handling_324-1}

London has river boat services on the Thames known as [Thames Clippers](/wiki/Thames_Clippers "Thames Clippers"), which offer both commuter and tourist boat services.^[\[317\]](#cite_note-325)^ At major piers including [Canary Wharf](/wiki/Canary_Wharf_Pier "Canary Wharf Pier"), [London Bridge City](/wiki/London_Bridge_City_Pier "London Bridge City Pier"), [Battersea Power Station](/wiki/Battersea_Power_Station "Battersea Power Station") and [London Eye](/wiki/London_Eye_Pier "London Eye Pier") (Waterloo), services depart at least every 20 minutes during commuter times.^[\[318\]](#cite_note-326)^ The [Woolwich Ferry](/wiki/Woolwich_Ferry "Woolwich Ferry"), with 2.5 million passengers every year, is a frequent service linking the [North](/wiki/North_Circular_Road,_London "North Circular Road, London") and [South Circular](/wiki/South_Circular_Road,_London "South Circular Road, London") Roads.^[\[319\]](#cite_note-327)^{#cite_ref-327}  

### Roads {#Roads}

Although the majority of journeys in central London are made by public transport, car travel is common in the suburbs. The [inner ring road](/wiki/London_Inner_Ring_Road "London Inner Ring Road") (around the city centre), the [North](/wiki/A406_road "A406 road") and [South Circular](/wiki/A205_road "A205 road") roads (just within the suburbs), and the outer orbital motorway (the [M25](/wiki/M25_motorway "M25 motorway"), just outside the built-up area in most places) encircle the city and are intersected by a number of busy radial routes---but very few motorways penetrate into [inner London](/wiki/Inner_London "Inner London"). The M25 is the second-longest ring-road motorway in Europe at 117 miles (188 km) long.^[\[320\]](#cite_note-328)^ The [A1](/wiki/A1_road_(Great_Britain) "A1 road (Great Britain)") and [M1](/wiki/M1_motorway "M1 motorway") connect London to [Leeds](/wiki/Leeds "Leeds"), and [Newcastle](/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne "Newcastle upon Tyne") and [Edinburgh](/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh").^[\[321\]](#cite_note-329)^{#cite_ref-329}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_(cropped).jpg) The [hackney carriage](/wiki/Hackney_carriage "Hackney carriage") (black cab) is a common sight on London streets. Black has been its standard colour since the [Austin FX3](/wiki/Austin_FX3 "Austin FX3") model in 1948.

The [Austin Motor Company](/wiki/Austin_Motor_Company "Austin Motor Company") began making [hackney carriages](/wiki/Hackney_carriage "Hackney carriage") (London taxis) in 1929, and models include [Austin FX3](/wiki/Austin_FX3 "Austin FX3") from 1948, [Austin FX4](/wiki/Austin_FX4 "Austin FX4") from 1958, with more recent models [TXII](/wiki/TXII "TXII") and [TX4](/wiki/TX4 "TX4") manufactured by [London Taxis International](/wiki/London_Taxis_International "London Taxis International"). The BBC states, "ubiquitous black cabs and red double-decker buses all have long and tangled stories that are deeply embedded in London's traditions".^[\[322\]](#cite_note-London_traditions-330)^ Although traditionally black, some are painted in other colours or bear advertising.^[\[323\]](#cite_note-331)^{#cite_ref-331}

London is notorious for its traffic congestion; in 2009, the average speed of a car in the rush hour was recorded at 10.6 mph (17.1 km/h).^[\[324\]](#cite_note-332)^ In 2003, a [congestion charge](/wiki/London_congestion_charge "London congestion charge") was introduced to reduce traffic volumes in the city centre. With a few exceptions, motorists are required to pay to drive within a defined zone encompassing much of central London.^[\[325\]](#cite_note-333)^ Motorists who are residents of the defined zone can buy a greatly reduced season pass.^[\[326\]](#cite_note-334)^ Over the course of several years, the average number of cars entering the centre of London on a weekday was reduced from 195,000 to 125,000.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-335)^{#cite_ref-335}

[Low Traffic Neighbourhoods (LTN)](/wiki/Low_Traffic_Neighbourhood "Low Traffic Neighbourhood") were widely introduced in London, but in 2023 the Department for Transport stopped funding them, even though the benefits outweighed the costs by approximately 100 times in the first 20 years and the difference is growing over time.^[\[328\]](#cite_note-336)^{#cite_ref-336}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

Main article: [Education in London](/wiki/Education_in_London "Education in London")  

### Tertiary education {#Tertiary_education}

See also: [List of universities and higher education colleges in London](/wiki/List_of_universities_and_higher_education_colleges_in_London "List of universities and higher education colleges in London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg/220px-University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_(1).jpg) [University College London](/wiki/University_College_London "University College London") (UCL), established by Royal Charter in 1836, is one of the founding colleges of the [University of London](/wiki/University_of_London "University of London"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg/220px-Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg)](/wiki/File:Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg) [Imperial College London](/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London"), a technical research university focusing on science, engineering, medicine and business, in [South Kensington](/wiki/South_Kensington "South Kensington") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg/220px-Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:Centre_Building,_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg) The [London School of Economics](/wiki/London_School_of_Economics "London School of Economics") (Centre Building pictured) was established in 1895

London is a major global centre of higher education teaching and research and has the largest concentration of higher education institutes in Europe.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-london2-27)^ According to the QS World University Rankings 2015/16, London has the greatest concentration of top class universities in the world^[\[329\]](#cite_note-337)^ and its international student population of around 110,000 is larger than any other city in the world.^[\[330\]](#cite_note-338)^ A 2014 [PricewaterhouseCoopers](/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers "PricewaterhouseCoopers") report termed London the global capital of higher education.^[\[331\]](#cite_note-339)^ A number of world-leading education institutions are based in London. In the 2022 *[QS World University Rankings](/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings "QS World University Rankings")* , [Imperial College London](/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London") is ranked No. 6 in the world, [University College London](/wiki/University_College_London "University College London") (UCL) is ranked 8th, and [King's College London](/wiki/King%27s_College_London "King's College London") (KCL) is ranked 37th.^[\[332\]](#cite_note-340)^ All are regularly ranked highly, with Imperial College being the UK's leading university in the [Research Excellence Framework](/wiki/Research_Excellence_Framework "Research Excellence Framework") ranking 2021.^[\[333\]](#cite_note-341)^ The [London School of Economics](/wiki/London_School_of_Economics "London School of Economics") (LSE) has been described as the world's leading social science institution for both teaching and research.^[\[334\]](#cite_note-london_156-342)^ The [London Business School](/wiki/London_Business_School "London Business School") is considered one of the world's leading business schools and in 2015 its MBA programme was ranked second-best in the world by the *[Financial Times](/wiki/Financial_Times "Financial Times")* .^[\[335\]](#cite_note-ft-343)^ The city is also home to three of the world's top ten performing arts schools (as ranked by the 2020 QS World University Rankings^[\[336\]](#cite_note-344)^): the [Royal College of Music](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music "Royal College of Music") (ranking 2nd in the world), the [Royal Academy of Music](/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music "Royal Academy of Music") (ranking 4th) and the [Guildhall School of Music and Drama](/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama "Guildhall School of Music and Drama") (ranking 6th).^[\[337\]](#cite_note-345)^{#cite_ref-345}

With students in London and around 48,000 in [University of London Worldwide](/wiki/University_of_London_Worldwide "University of London Worldwide"),^[\[338\]](#cite_note-External-346)^ the federal [University of London](/wiki/University_of_London "University of London") is the largest contact teaching university in the UK.^[\[339\]](#cite_note-347)^ It includes five multi-faculty universities -- [City](/wiki/City,_University_of_London "City, University of London"), King's College London, [Queen Mary](/wiki/Queen_Mary,_University_of_London "Queen Mary, University of London"), [Royal Holloway](/wiki/Royal_Holloway "Royal Holloway") and UCL -- and a number of smaller and more specialised institutions including [Birkbeck](/wiki/Birkbeck_College "Birkbeck College"), the [Courtauld Institute of Art](/wiki/Courtauld_Institute_of_Art "Courtauld Institute of Art"), [Goldsmiths](/wiki/Goldsmiths,_University_of_London "Goldsmiths, University of London"), the London Business School, the London School of Economics, the [London School of Hygiene \& Tropical Medicine](/wiki/London_School_of_Hygiene_%26_Tropical_Medicine "London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine"), the [Royal Academy of Music](/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music "Royal Academy of Music"), the [Central School of Speech and Drama](/wiki/Central_School_of_Speech_and_Drama "Central School of Speech and Drama"), the [Royal Veterinary College](/wiki/Royal_Veterinary_College "Royal Veterinary College") and the [School of Oriental and African Studies](/wiki/School_of_Oriental_and_African_Studies "School of Oriental and African Studies").^[\[340\]](#cite_note-348)^{#cite_ref-348}

Universities in London outside the University of London system include [Brunel University](/wiki/Brunel_University "Brunel University"), [Imperial College London](/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London"),^[\[h\]](#cite_note-349)^ [Kingston University](/wiki/Kingston_University "Kingston University"), [London Metropolitan University](/wiki/London_Metropolitan_University "London Metropolitan University"), [University of East London](/wiki/University_of_East_London "University of East London"), [University of West London](/wiki/University_of_West_London "University of West London"), [University of Westminster](/wiki/University_of_Westminster "University of Westminster"), [London South Bank University](/wiki/London_South_Bank_University "London South Bank University"), [Middlesex University](/wiki/Middlesex_University "Middlesex University"), and [University of the Arts London](/wiki/University_of_the_Arts_London "University of the Arts London") (the largest university of art, design, fashion, communication and the performing arts in Europe).^[\[341\]](#cite_note-350)^ In addition, there are three international universities -- [Regent's University London](/wiki/Regent%27s_College "Regent's College"), [Richmond, The American International University in London](/wiki/Richmond,_The_American_International_University_in_London "Richmond, The American International University in London") and [Schiller International University](/wiki/Schiller_International_University "Schiller International University").{#cite_ref-350}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg/220px-KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg)](/wiki/File:KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg) [King's College London](/wiki/King%27s_College_London "King's College London")'s [Guy's Campus](/wiki/Guy%27s_Campus "Guy's Campus"), home to the university's [Faculty of Life Sciences \& Medicine](/wiki/King%27s_College_London_School_of_Medicine "King's College London School of Medicine")

London is home to [five major medical schools](/wiki/United_Hospitals "United Hospitals") -- [Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry](/wiki/Barts_and_The_London_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry "Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry") (part of [Queen Mary](/wiki/Queen_Mary,_University_of_London "Queen Mary, University of London")), [King's College London School of Medicine](/wiki/King%27s_College_London_School_of_Medicine "King's College London School of Medicine") (the largest medical school in Europe), [Imperial College School of Medicine](/wiki/Imperial_College_School_of_Medicine "Imperial College School of Medicine"), [UCL Medical School](/wiki/UCL_Medical_School "UCL Medical School") and [St George's, University of London](/wiki/St_George%27s,_University_of_London "St George's, University of London") -- and has many affiliated teaching hospitals. It is also a major centre for biomedical research, and three of the UK's eight [academic health science centres](/wiki/Academic_health_science_centre "Academic health science centre") are based in the city -- [Imperial College Healthcare](/wiki/Imperial_College_Healthcare_NHS_Trust "Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust"), [King's Health Partners](/wiki/King%27s_Health_Partners "King's Health Partners") and [UCL Partners](/wiki/UCL_Partners "UCL Partners") (the largest such centre in Europe).^[\[342\]](#cite_note-351)^ Additionally, many biomedical and biotechnology spin out companies from these research institutions are based around the city, most prominently in [White City](/wiki/White_City,_London "White City, London"). Founded by pioneering nurse [Florence Nightingale](/wiki/Florence_Nightingale "Florence Nightingale") at [St Thomas' Hospital](/wiki/St_Thomas%27_Hospital "St Thomas' Hospital") in 1860, the [first nursing school](/wiki/Florence_Nightingale_Faculty_of_Nursing_and_Midwifery "Florence Nightingale Faculty of Nursing and Midwifery") is now part of King's College London.^[\[343\]](#cite_note-352)^ It was at King's in 1952 where a team led by [Rosalind Franklin](/wiki/Rosalind_Franklin "Rosalind Franklin") captured *[Photo 51](/wiki/Photo_51 "Photo 51")* , the critical evidence in identifying the structure of [DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA").^[\[344\]](#cite_note-353)^ There are a number of business schools in London, including the [London School of Business and Finance](/wiki/London_School_of_Business_and_Finance "London School of Business and Finance"), [Cass Business School](/wiki/Cass_Business_School "Cass Business School") (part of [City University London](/wiki/City_University_London "City University London")), [Hult International Business School](/wiki/Hult_International_Business_School "Hult International Business School"), [ESCP Europe](/wiki/ESCP_Europe "ESCP Europe"), [European Business School London](/wiki/European_Business_School_London "European Business School London"), [Imperial College Business School](/wiki/Imperial_College_Business_School "Imperial College Business School"), the [London Business School](/wiki/London_Business_School "London Business School") and the [UCL School of Management](/wiki/UCL_School_of_Management "UCL School of Management").{#cite_ref-353}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg/200px-Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg)](/wiki/File:Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg) Opened in 1904, [RADA](/wiki/RADA "RADA") (Royal Academy of Dramatic Art) is a member of the UK's [Federation of Drama Schools](/wiki/Federation_of_Drama_Schools "Federation of Drama Schools").

London is also home to many specialist arts education institutions, including esteemed drama schools such as [RADA](/wiki/RADA "RADA") (Royal Academy of Dramatic Art), the [London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art](/wiki/London_Academy_of_Music_and_Dramatic_Art "London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art") (LAMDA), [Drama Studio London](/wiki/Drama_Studio_London "Drama Studio London"), [Sylvia Young Theatre School](/wiki/Sylvia_Young_Theatre_School "Sylvia Young Theatre School"), the [Royal Central School of Speech and Drama](/wiki/Royal_Central_School_of_Speech_and_Drama "Royal Central School of Speech and Drama") and the [Guildhall School of Music and Drama](/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama "Guildhall School of Music and Drama"), as well as the [London College of Contemporary Arts](/wiki/London_College_of_Contemporary_Arts "London College of Contemporary Arts") (LCCA), [Central School of Ballet](/wiki/Central_School_of_Ballet "Central School of Ballet"), [London Contemporary Dance School](/wiki/London_Contemporary_Dance_School "London Contemporary Dance School"), [National Centre for Circus Arts](/wiki/The_Circus_Space "The Circus Space"), [Rambert School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance](/wiki/Rambert_Dance_Company "Rambert Dance Company"), the [Royal College of Art](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art "Royal College of Art"), and [Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance](/wiki/Trinity_Laban_Conservatoire_of_Music_and_Dance "Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance"). The [BRIT School](/wiki/BRIT_School "BRIT School") in the London borough of Croydon provides training for the performing arts and technologies.^[\[345\]](#cite_note-354)^{#cite_ref-354}  

### Primary and secondary education {#Primary_and_secondary_education}

See also: [Centre for School Design](/wiki/Centre_for_School_Design "Centre for School Design")

The majority of primary and secondary schools and further-education colleges in London are controlled by the [London boroughs](/wiki/London_boroughs "London boroughs") or otherwise state-funded; leading examples include [Ashbourne College](/wiki/Ashbourne_College "Ashbourne College"), [Bethnal Green Academy](/wiki/Bethnal_Green_Academy "Bethnal Green Academy"), [Brampton Manor Academy](/wiki/Brampton_Manor_Academy "Brampton Manor Academy"), [City and Islington College](/wiki/City_and_Islington_College "City and Islington College"), [City of Westminster College](/wiki/City_of_Westminster_College "City of Westminster College"), [David Game College](/wiki/David_Game_College "David Game College"), [Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College](/wiki/Ealing,_Hammersmith_and_West_London_College "Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College"), [Leyton Sixth Form College](/wiki/Leyton_Sixth_Form_College "Leyton Sixth Form College"), [London Academy of Excellence](/wiki/London_Academy_of_Excellence "London Academy of Excellence"), [Tower Hamlets College](/wiki/Tower_Hamlets_College "Tower Hamlets College"), and [Newham Collegiate Sixth Form Centre](/wiki/Newham_Collegiate_Sixth_Form_Centre "Newham Collegiate Sixth Form Centre"). There are also a number of private schools and colleges in London, some old and famous, such as [City of London School](/wiki/City_of_London_School "City of London School"), [Harrow](/wiki/Harrow_School "Harrow School") (alumni includes seven former British prime ministers), [St Paul's School](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_School,_London "St Paul's School, London"), [Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School](/wiki/Haberdashers%27_Aske%27s_Boys%27_School "Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School"), [University College School](/wiki/University_College_School "University College School"), [The John Lyon School](/wiki/The_John_Lyon_School "The John Lyon School"), [Highgate School](/wiki/Highgate_School "Highgate School") and [Westminster School](/wiki/Westminster_School "Westminster School").^[\[346\]](#cite_note-355)^{#cite_ref-355}  

### Royal Observatory, Greenwich and learned societies {#Royal_Observatory.2C_Greenwich_and_learned_societies}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg/220px-Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument,_Greenwich_Observatory,_London.jpg) Tourists queuing to take pictures on the line of the historic [prime meridian](/wiki/Prime_meridian_(Greenwich) "Prime meridian (Greenwich)") at the [Royal Observatory, Greenwich](/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich "Royal Observatory, Greenwich").

Founded in 1675, the [Royal Observatory](/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich "Royal Observatory, Greenwich") in [Greenwich](/wiki/Greenwich "Greenwich") was established to address the problem of calculating [longitude](/wiki/Longitude "Longitude") for navigational purposes. This pioneering work in solving longitude featured in astronomer royal [Nevil Maskelyne](/wiki/Nevil_Maskelyne "Nevil Maskelyne")'s *[Nautical Almanac](/wiki/Nautical_Almanac "Nautical Almanac")* which made the Greenwich meridian the universal reference point, and helped lead to the international adoption of Greenwich as the [prime meridian](/wiki/Prime_meridian "Prime meridian") (0° longitude) in 1884.^[\[347\]](#cite_note-356)^{#cite_ref-356}

Important scientific [learned societies](/wiki/Learned_societies "Learned societies") based in London include the [Royal Society](/wiki/Royal_Society "Royal Society")---the UK's national [academy of sciences](/wiki/Academy_of_sciences "Academy of sciences") and the oldest national scientific institution in the world---founded in 1660,^[\[348\]](#cite_note-357)^ and the [Royal Institution](/wiki/Royal_Institution "Royal Institution"), founded in 1799. Since 1825, the [Royal Institution Christmas Lectures](/wiki/Royal_Institution_Christmas_Lectures "Royal Institution Christmas Lectures") have presented scientific subjects to a general audience, and speakers have included physicist and inventor [Michael Faraday](/wiki/Michael_Faraday "Michael Faraday"), aerospace engineer [Frank Whittle](/wiki/Frank_Whittle "Frank Whittle"), naturalist [David Attenborough](/wiki/David_Attenborough "David Attenborough") and evolutionary biologist [Richard Dawkins](/wiki/Richard_Dawkins "Richard Dawkins").^[\[349\]](#cite_note-358)^{#cite_ref-358}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

Main article: [Culture of London](/wiki/Culture_of_London "Culture of London")  

### Leisure and entertainment {#Leisure_and_entertainment}

See also: [List of annual events in London](/wiki/List_of_annual_events_in_London "List of annual events in London") and [West End theatre](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West End theatre")

Leisure is a major part of the London economy. A 2003 report attributed a quarter of the entire UK leisure economy to London^[\[350\]](#cite_note-359)^ at 25.6 events per 1000 people.^[\[351\]](#cite_note-360)^ The city is one of the four [fashion capitals](/wiki/Fashion_capital "Fashion capital") of the world, and, according to official statistics, is the world's third-busiest film production centre, presents more live comedy than any other city,^[\[352\]](#cite_note-361)^ and has the biggest theatre audience of any city in the world.^[\[353\]](#cite_note-362)^{#cite_ref-362}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/170px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Harrods_at_Night,_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg) [Harrods](/wiki/Harrods "Harrods") department store in [Knightsbridge](/wiki/Knightsbridge "Knightsbridge")

Within the [City of Westminster](/wiki/City_of_Westminster "City of Westminster"), the entertainment district of the [West End](/wiki/West_End_of_London "West End of London") has its focus around [Leicester Square](/wiki/Leicester_Square "Leicester Square"), where London and world film [premieres](/wiki/Premiere "Premiere") are held, and [Piccadilly Circus](/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus "Piccadilly Circus"), with its giant electronic advertisements.^[\[354\]](#cite_note-london_160-363)^ London's [theatre district](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West End theatre") is here, as are many cinemas, bars, clubs, and restaurants, including the city's [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_London "Chinatown, London") district (in [Soho](/wiki/Soho "Soho")), and just to the east is [Covent Garden](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House "Royal Opera House"), an area housing speciality shops. In 1881, the West End's [Savoy Theatre](/wiki/Savoy_Theatre "Savoy Theatre"), which was built to showcase the plays of [Gilbert and Sullivan](/wiki/Gilbert_and_Sullivan "Gilbert and Sullivan"), was fitted with the incandescent light bulb developed by Sir [Joseph Swan](/wiki/Joseph_Swan "Joseph Swan") to become the first public building in the world to be lit entirely by electricity.^[\[355\]](#cite_note-364)^ The city is the home of [Andrew Lloyd Webber](/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber "Andrew Lloyd Webber"), whose musicals have dominated West End theatre since the late 20th century.^[\[356\]](#cite_note-365)^ [Agatha Christie](/wiki/Agatha_Christie "Agatha Christie")'s *[The Mousetrap](/wiki/The_Mousetrap "The Mousetrap")* , the world's longest-running play, has been performed in the West End since 1952.^[\[357\]](#cite_note-366)^ The [Laurence Olivier Awards](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier_Awards "Laurence Olivier Awards")--named after [Laurence Olivier](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier "Laurence Olivier")--are given annually by the [Society of London Theatre](/wiki/Society_of_London_Theatre "Society of London Theatre"). The [Royal Ballet](/wiki/Royal_Ballet "Royal Ballet"), [English National Ballet](/wiki/English_National_Ballet "English National Ballet"), [Royal Opera](/wiki/Royal_Opera,_London "Royal Opera, London"), and [English National Opera](/wiki/English_National_Opera "English National Opera") are based in London and perform at the [Royal Opera House](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House "Royal Opera House"), the [London Coliseum](/wiki/London_Coliseum "London Coliseum"), [Sadler's Wells Theatre](/wiki/Sadler%27s_Wells_Theatre "Sadler's Wells Theatre"), and the [Royal Albert Hall](/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall "Royal Albert Hall"), as well as touring the country.^[\[358\]](#cite_note-London's_Concerts-367)^{#cite_ref-London's_Concerts_367-0}

[Islington](/wiki/Islington "Islington")'s 1 mile (1.6 km) long [Upper Street](/wiki/Upper_Street "Upper Street"), extending northwards from [Angel](/wiki/Angel,_London "Angel, London"), has more bars and restaurants than any other street in the UK.^[\[359\]](#cite_note-london_161-368)^ Europe's busiest shopping area is [Oxford Street](/wiki/Oxford_Street "Oxford Street"), a shopping street nearly 1 mile (1.6 km) long, making it the longest shopping street in the UK. It is home to vast numbers of retailers and [department stores](/wiki/Department_stores "Department stores"), including [Selfridges](/wiki/Selfridges "Selfridges") [flagship store](/wiki/Flagship_store#Retailing "Flagship store").^[\[360\]](#cite_note-369)^ [Knightsbridge](/wiki/Knightsbridge "Knightsbridge"), home to the equally renowned [Harrods](/wiki/Harrods "Harrods") department store, lies to the south-west. One of the world's largest retail destinations, London frequently ranks at or near the top of retail sales of any city.^[\[361\]](#cite_note-370)^^[\[362\]](#cite_note-371)^ Opened in 1760 with its flagship store on [Regent Street](/wiki/Regent_Street "Regent Street") since 1881, [Hamleys](/wiki/Hamleys "Hamleys") is the oldest [toy store](/wiki/Toy_store "Toy store") in the world.^[\[363\]](#cite_note-372)^ The [Camden Town shoe retailer](/wiki/British_Boot_Company "British Boot Company") of [Dr. Martens](/wiki/Dr._Martens "Dr. Martens") footwear was a favourite haunt of punk musicians.^[\[364\]](#cite_note-373)^ [Madame Tussauds](/wiki/Madame_Tussauds "Madame Tussauds") wax museum opened in [Baker Street](/wiki/Baker_Street "Baker Street") in 1835, an era viewed as being when London's tourism industry began.^[\[365\]](#cite_note-374)^{#cite_ref-374}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Notting_hill_carnival.jpg/170px-Notting_hill_carnival.jpg)](/wiki/File:Notting_hill_carnival.jpg) Scene of the annual [Notting Hill Carnival](/wiki/Notting_Hill_Carnival "Notting Hill Carnival"), 2014

London is home to designers [John Galliano](/wiki/John_Galliano "John Galliano"), [Stella McCartney](/wiki/Stella_McCartney "Stella McCartney"), [Manolo Blahnik](/wiki/Manolo_Blahnik "Manolo Blahnik"), and [Jimmy Choo](/wiki/Jimmy_Choo "Jimmy Choo"), among others; its renowned art and fashion schools make it one of the four international centres of fashion. [Mary Quant](/wiki/Mary_Quant "Mary Quant") designed the [miniskirt](/wiki/Miniskirt "Miniskirt") in her [King's Road](/wiki/King%27s_Road "King's Road") boutique in [Swinging Sixties London](/wiki/Swinging_Sixties "Swinging Sixties").^[\[366\]](#cite_note-375)^ In 2017, London was ranked the top city for luxury store openings.^[\[367\]](#cite_note-376)^ [London Fashion Week](/wiki/London_Fashion_Week "London Fashion Week") takes place twice a year, in February and September; exhibitions have included *[Jack the Ripper Stalks His Victims](/wiki/Jack_the_Ripper_Stalks_His_Victims "Jack the Ripper Stalks His Victims")* , the first collection by [Alexander McQueen](/wiki/Alexander_McQueen "Alexander McQueen").^[\[368\]](#cite_note-377)^ Londoners on the catwalk have included [Naomi Campbell](/wiki/Naomi_Campbell "Naomi Campbell"), [Kate Moss](/wiki/Kate_Moss "Kate Moss") and [Cara Delevingne](/wiki/Cara_Delevingne "Cara Delevingne").^[\[369\]](#cite_note-378)^{#cite_ref-378}

London offers a great variety of cuisine as a result of its ethnically diverse population. Gastronomic centres include the Bangladeshi restaurants of [Brick Lane](/wiki/Brick_Lane "Brick Lane") and the [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_food "Chinese food") restaurants of [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_London "Chinatown, London").^[\[370\]](#cite_note-379)^ There are [Chinese takeaways](/wiki/Chinese_takeaway "Chinese takeaway") throughout London, as are Indian restaurants which provide [Indian and Anglo-Indian cuisine](/wiki/English_cuisine#Indian_and_Anglo-Indian_cuisine "English cuisine").^[\[371\]](#cite_note-380)^ Around 1860, the first [fish and chips](/wiki/Fish_and_chips "Fish and chips") shop in London was opened by Joseph Malin, a Jewish immigrant, in [Bow](/wiki/Bow,_London "Bow, London").^[\[322\]](#cite_note-London_traditions-330)^ The [full English breakfast](/wiki/Full_English_breakfast "Full English breakfast") dates from the Victorian era, and many [cafes](/wiki/Cafe_(British) "Cafe (British)") in London serve a full English throughout the day.^[\[372\]](#cite_note-381)^ London has five 3-Michelin star restaurants, including [Restaurant Gordon Ramsay](/wiki/Restaurant_Gordon_Ramsay "Restaurant Gordon Ramsay") in [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea,_London "Chelsea, London").^[\[373\]](#cite_note-382)^ Many hotels in London provide a traditional [afternoon tea](/wiki/Afternoon_tea "Afternoon tea") service, such as the [Oscar Wilde Lounge](/wiki/Hotel_Caf%C3%A9_Royal#Restoration_and_conversion "Hotel Café Royal") at the [Hotel Café Royal](/wiki/Hotel_Caf%C3%A9_Royal "Hotel Café Royal") in Piccadilly, and a themed tea service is also available, for example an *[Alice in Wonderland](/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland")* themed afternoon tea served at the [Egerton House Hotel](/wiki/Egerton_House_Hotel "Egerton House Hotel"), and *[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory](/wiki/Charlie_and_the_Chocolate_Factory "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory")* themed afternoon tea at [One Aldwych](/wiki/One_Aldwych "One Aldwych") in Covent Garden.^[\[374\]](#cite_note-383)^^[\[375\]](#cite_note-384)^ The nation's most popular [biscuit](/wiki/Biscuit "Biscuit") to [dunk](/wiki/Dunking_(biscuit) "Dunking (biscuit)") in tea, [chocolate digestives](/wiki/Chocolate_digestive "Chocolate digestive") have been manufactured by [McVitie's](/wiki/McVitie%27s "McVitie's") at their [Harlesden](/wiki/Harlesden "Harlesden") factory in north-west London since 1925.^[\[376\]](#cite_note-385)^{#cite_ref-385}
