[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/220px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg)](/wiki/File:Restaurante_The_Swan,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_113.jpg) [Shakespeare's Globe](/wiki/Shakespeare%27s_Globe "Shakespeare's Globe") is a modern reconstruction of the Globe Theatre on the south bank of the Thames.

There is a variety of [annual events](/wiki/List_of_annual_events_in_London "List of annual events in London"), beginning with the relatively new [New Year's Day Parade](/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day_Parade "New Year's Day Parade"), a fireworks display at the [London Eye](/wiki/London_Eye "London Eye"); the world's second largest [street party](/wiki/Street_party "Street party"), the [Notting Hill Carnival](/wiki/Notting_Hill_Carnival "Notting Hill Carnival"), is held on the late [August Bank Holiday](/wiki/August_Bank_Holiday "August Bank Holiday") each year. Traditional parades include November's [Lord Mayor's Show](/wiki/Lord_Mayor%27s_Show "Lord Mayor's Show"), a centuries-old event celebrating the annual appointment of a new [Lord Mayor of the City of London](/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_the_City_of_London "Lord Mayor of the City of London") with a procession along the streets of the city, and June's [Trooping the Colour](/wiki/Trooping_the_Colour "Trooping the Colour"), a formal military pageant performed by regiments of the [Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") and [British](/wiki/British_Army "British Army") armies to celebrate the [King's Official Birthday](/wiki/King%27s_Official_Birthday "King's Official Birthday").^[\[377\]](#cite_note-386)^ The [Boishakhi Mela](/wiki/Boishakhi_Mela "Boishakhi Mela") is a [Bengali New Year](/wiki/Bengali_New_Year "Bengali New Year") festival celebrated by the [British Bangladeshi](/wiki/British_Bangladeshi "British Bangladeshi") community. It is the largest open-air Asian festival in Europe. After the Notting Hill Carnival, it is the second-largest street festival in the United Kingdom attracting over 80,000 visitors.^[\[378\]](#cite_note-387)^ First held in 1862, the [RHS Chelsea Flower Show](/wiki/Chelsea_Flower_Show "Chelsea Flower Show") (run by the [Royal Horticultural Society](/wiki/Royal_Horticultural_Society "Royal Horticultural Society")) takes place in May every year.^[\[379\]](#cite_note-388)^{#cite_ref-388}  

### LGBT scene {#LGBT_scene}

Main article: [LGBT culture in London](/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_London "LGBT culture in London")

The first [gay bar](/wiki/Gay_bar "Gay bar") in London in the modern sense was [The Cave of the Golden Calf](/wiki/The_Cave_of_the_Golden_Calf "The Cave of the Golden Calf"), established as a night club in an underground location at 9 Heddon Street, just off [Regent Street](/wiki/Regent_Street "Regent Street"), in 1912 and "which developed a reputation for sexual freedom and tolerance of same-sex relations".^[\[380\]](#cite_note-389)^{#cite_ref-389}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/170px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg)](/wiki/File:Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg) [Comptons of Soho](/wiki/Comptons_of_Soho "Comptons of Soho") during [London Pride](/wiki/Pride_in_London "Pride in London") in 2010

While London has been an LGBT tourism destination, after [homosexuality was decriminalised](/wiki/Sexual_Offences_Act_1967 "Sexual Offences Act 1967") in England in 1967 gay bar culture became more visible, and from the early 1970s [Soho](/wiki/Soho "Soho") (and in particular [Old Compton Street](/wiki/Old_Compton_Street "Old Compton Street")) became the centre of the [London LGBT community](/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_London "LGBT culture in London").^[\[381\]](#cite_note-Olson-390)^ [G-A-Y](/wiki/G-A-Y "G-A-Y"), previously based at the [Astoria](/wiki/London_Astoria "London Astoria"), and now [Heaven](/wiki/Heaven_(nightclub) "Heaven (nightclub)"), is a long-running night club.^[\[382\]](#cite_note-391)^{#cite_ref-391}

Wider British cultural movements have influenced LGBT culture: for example, the emergence of [glam rock](/wiki/Glam_rock "Glam rock") in the UK in the early 1970s, via [Marc Bolan](/wiki/Marc_Bolan "Marc Bolan") and [David Bowie](/wiki/David_Bowie "David Bowie"), saw a generation of teenagers begin playing with the idea of androgyny, and the West End musical *[The Rocky Horror Show](/wiki/The_Rocky_Horror_Show "The Rocky Horror Show")* , which debuted in London in 1973, is also widely said to have been an influence on countercultural and sexual liberation movements.^[\[383\]](#cite_note-392)^ The [Blitz Kids](/wiki/Blitz_Kids "Blitz Kids") (which included [Boy George](/wiki/Boy_George "Boy George")) frequented the Tuesday club-night at Blitz in [Covent Garden](/wiki/Covent_Garden "Covent Garden"), helping launch the [New Romantic](/wiki/New_Romantic "New Romantic") subcultural movement in the late 1970s.^[\[384\]](#cite_note-393)^ Today, the annual [London Pride Parade](/wiki/Pride_in_London "Pride in London") and the [London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival](/wiki/London_Lesbian_and_Gay_Film_Festival "London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival") are held in the city.^[\[381\]](#cite_note-Olson-390)^{#cite_ref-Olson_390-1}  

### Literature, film and television {#Literature.2C_film_and_television}

Main articles: [London in fiction](/wiki/London_in_fiction "London in fiction"), [London in film](/wiki/London_in_film "London in film"), [List of television shows set in London](/wiki/List_of_television_shows_set_in_London "List of television shows set in London"), and [London Television Archive](/wiki/London_Television_Archive "London Television Archive")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/220px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg) [Sherlock Holmes Museum](/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum "Sherlock Holmes Museum") in [Baker Street](/wiki/Baker_Street "Baker Street"), bearing the number 221B

London has been the setting for many works of literature. The pilgrims in [Geoffrey Chaucer](/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer "Geoffrey Chaucer")'s late 14th-century *[Canterbury Tales](/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales "The Canterbury Tales")* set out for [Canterbury](/wiki/Canterbury "Canterbury") from London. [William Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare") spent a large part of his life living and working in London; his contemporary [Ben Jonson](/wiki/Ben_Jonson "Ben Jonson") was also based there, and some of his work, most notably his play *[The Alchemist](/wiki/The_Alchemist_(play) "The Alchemist (play)")* , was set in the city.^[\[385\]](#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394)^ *[A Journal of the Plague Year](/wiki/A_Journal_of_the_Plague_Year "A Journal of the Plague Year")* (1722) by [Daniel Defoe](/wiki/Daniel_Defoe "Daniel Defoe") is a fictionalisation of the events of the 1665 [Great Plague](/wiki/Great_Plague_of_London "Great Plague of London").^[\[385\]](#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394)^{#cite_ref-London_in_Literature_394-1}

The literary centres of London have traditionally been hilly [Hampstead](/wiki/Hampstead "Hampstead") and (since the early 20th century) [Bloomsbury](/wiki/Bloomsbury "Bloomsbury"). Writers closely associated with the city are the diarist [Samuel Pepys](/wiki/Samuel_Pepys "Samuel Pepys"), noted for his eyewitness account of the [Great Fire](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London "Great Fire of London"); [Charles Dickens](/wiki/Charles_Dickens "Charles Dickens"), whose representation of a foggy, snowy, grimy London of street sweepers and pickpockets has influenced people's vision of early [Victorian](/wiki/Victorian_era "Victorian era") London; and [Virginia Woolf](/wiki/Virginia_Woolf "Virginia Woolf"), regarded as one of the foremost [modernist](/wiki/Modernist_literature "Modernist literature") literary figures of the 20th century.^[\[385\]](#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394)^ Later important depictions of London from the 19th and early 20th centuries are [Arthur Conan Doyle](/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle "Arthur Conan Doyle")'s [Sherlock Holmes](/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes "Sherlock Holmes") stories.^[\[385\]](#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394)^ [Robert Louis Stevenson](/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson "Robert Louis Stevenson") mixed in London literary circles, and in 1886 he wrote the *[Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde](/wiki/Strange_Case_of_Dr_Jekyll_and_Mr_Hyde "Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde")* , a [gothic](/wiki/Gothic_fiction "Gothic fiction") novella set in Victorian London.^[\[386\]](#cite_note-395)^ In 1898, [H. G. Wells](/wiki/H._G._Wells "H. G. Wells")' sci-fi novel *[The War of the Worlds](/wiki/The_War_of_the_Worlds "The War of the Worlds")* sees London (and southern England) invaded by Martians.^[\[387\]](#cite_note-396)^ [Letitia Elizabeth Landon](/wiki/Letitia_Elizabeth_Landon "Letitia Elizabeth Landon") wrote *Calendar of the London Seasons* in 1834. Modern writers influenced by the city include [Peter Ackroyd](/wiki/Peter_Ackroyd "Peter Ackroyd"), author of *[London: The Biography](/wiki/London:_The_Biography "London: The Biography")* , and [Iain Sinclair](/wiki/Iain_Sinclair "Iain Sinclair"), who writes in the genre of [psychogeography](/wiki/Psychogeography "Psychogeography"). In the 1940s, [George Orwell](/wiki/George_Orwell "George Orwell") wrote essays in the *[London Evening Standard](/wiki/Evening_Standard "Evening Standard")* , including "[A Nice Cup of Tea](/wiki/A_Nice_Cup_of_Tea "A Nice Cup of Tea")" (method for making tea) and "[The Moon Under Water](/wiki/The_Moon_Under_Water "The Moon Under Water")" (an ideal [pub](/wiki/Pub "Pub")).^[\[388\]](#cite_note-397)^ The WWII [evacuation of children from London](/wiki/Evacuations_of_civilians_in_Britain_during_World_War_II "Evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II") is depicted in [C. S. Lewis](/wiki/C._S._Lewis "C. S. Lewis")' first Narnia book *[The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe](/wiki/The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe")* (1950). On Christmas Eve 1925, [Winnie-the-Pooh](/wiki/Winnie-the-Pooh "Winnie-the-Pooh") debuted in London's *[Evening News](/wiki/The_Evening_News_(London_newspaper) "The Evening News (London newspaper)")* , with the character based on a stuffed toy [A. A. Milne](/wiki/A._A._Milne "A. A. Milne") bought for his son [Christopher Robin](/wiki/Christopher_Robin_Milne "Christopher Robin Milne") in Harrods.^[\[389\]](#cite_note-398)^ In 1958, author [Michael Bond](/wiki/Michael_Bond "Michael Bond") created [Paddington Bear](/wiki/Paddington_Bear "Paddington Bear"), a refugee found in [Paddington station](/wiki/London_Paddington_station "London Paddington station"). A screen adaptation, *[Paddington](/wiki/Paddington_(film) "Paddington (film)")* (2014), features the calypso song "[London is the Place for Me](/wiki/London_is_the_Place_for_Me "London is the Place for Me")".^[\[390\]](#cite_note-399)^ Buckingham Palace features in [Roald Dahl](/wiki/Roald_Dahl "Roald Dahl")'s 1982 novel *[The BFG](/wiki/The_BFG "The BFG")* .^[\[391\]](#cite_note-400)^{#cite_ref-400}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wikisource-logo.svg)  
[Wikisource](/wiki/Wikisource "Wikisource") has original text related to this article:  
**['Calendar of the London Seasons', by L. E. L.](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Calendar_of_the_London_Seasons/Calendar_of_the_London_Seasons "wikisource:Calendar of the London Seasons/Calendar of the London Seasons")**
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/250px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_July_2010_(4818942309).jpg) Opened in 1937, the [Odeon cinema](/wiki/Odeon_Luxe_Leicester_Square "Odeon Luxe Leicester Square") in [Leicester Square](/wiki/Leicester_Square "Leicester Square") hosts numerous European and world film premieres.

London has played a significant role in the film industry. Major studios within or bordering London include [Pinewood](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios "Pinewood Studios"), [Elstree](/wiki/Elstree_Studios "Elstree Studios"), [Ealing](/wiki/Ealing_Studios "Ealing Studios"), [Shepperton](/wiki/Shepperton_Studios "Shepperton Studios"), [Twickenham](/wiki/Twickenham_Studios "Twickenham Studios"), and [Leavesden](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Studios_Leavesden "Warner Bros. Studios Leavesden"), with the *[James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond")* and *[Harry Potter](/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series) "Harry Potter (film series)")* series among many notable films produced here.^[\[392\]](#cite_note-401)^^[\[393\]](#cite_note-filmlondon-402)^ [Working Title Films](/wiki/Working_Title_Films "Working Title Films") has its headquarters in London. A [post-production](/wiki/Post-production "Post-production") community is centred in [Soho](/wiki/Soho "Soho"), and London houses six of the world's largest [visual effects](/wiki/Visual_effects "Visual effects") companies, such as [Framestore](/wiki/Framestore "Framestore").^[\[394\]](#cite_note-403)^ [The Imaginarium](/wiki/The_Imaginarium "The Imaginarium"), a digital performance-capture studio, was founded by [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis").^[\[395\]](#cite_note-404)^ London has been the setting for films including *[Oliver Twist](/wiki/Oliver_Twist_(1948_film) "Oliver Twist (1948 film)")* (1948), *[Scrooge](/wiki/Scrooge_(1951_film) "Scrooge (1951 film)")* (1951), *[Peter Pan](/wiki/Peter_Pan_(1953_film) "Peter Pan (1953 film)")* (1953), *[One Hundred and One Dalmatians](/wiki/One_Hundred_and_One_Dalmatians "One Hundred and One Dalmatians")* (1961), *[My Fair Lady](/wiki/My_Fair_Lady_(film) "My Fair Lady (film)")* (1964), *[Mary Poppins](/wiki/Mary_Poppins_(film) "Mary Poppins (film)")* (1964), *[Blowup](/wiki/Blowup "Blowup")* (1966), *[A Clockwork Orange](/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(film) "A Clockwork Orange (film)")* (1971), *[The Long Good Friday](/wiki/The_Long_Good_Friday "The Long Good Friday")* (1980), *[The Great Mouse Detective](/wiki/The_Great_Mouse_Detective "The Great Mouse Detective")* (1986), *[Notting Hill](/wiki/Notting_Hill_(film) "Notting Hill (film)")* (1999), *[Love Actually](/wiki/Love_Actually "Love Actually")* (2003), *[V for Vendetta](/wiki/V_for_Vendetta_(film) "V for Vendetta (film)")* (2005), *[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street](/wiki/Sweeney_Todd:_The_Demon_Barber_of_Fleet_Street "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street")* (2008), and *[The King's Speech](/wiki/The_King%27s_Speech "The King's Speech")* (2010). Notable actors and filmmakers from London include [Charlie Chaplin](/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin "Charlie Chaplin"), [Alfred Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred Hitchcock"), [Michael Caine](/wiki/Michael_Caine "Michael Caine"), [Julie Andrews](/wiki/Julie_Andrews "Julie Andrews"), [Peter Sellers](/wiki/Peter_Sellers "Peter Sellers"), [David Lean](/wiki/David_Lean "David Lean"), [Julie Christie](/wiki/Julie_Christie "Julie Christie"), [Gary Oldman](/wiki/Gary_Oldman "Gary Oldman"), [Emma Thompson](/wiki/Emma_Thompson "Emma Thompson"), [Guy Ritchie](/wiki/Guy_Ritchie "Guy Ritchie"), [Christopher Nolan](/wiki/Christopher_Nolan "Christopher Nolan"), [Alan Rickman](/wiki/Alan_Rickman "Alan Rickman"), [Jude Law](/wiki/Jude_Law "Jude Law"), [Helena Bonham Carter](/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter "Helena Bonham Carter"), [Idris Elba](/wiki/Idris_Elba "Idris Elba"), [Tom Hardy](/wiki/Tom_Hardy "Tom Hardy"), [Daniel Radcliffe](/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe "Daniel Radcliffe"), [Keira Knightley](/wiki/Keira_Knightley "Keira Knightley"), [Riz Ahmed](/wiki/Riz_Ahmed "Riz Ahmed"), [Dev Patel](/wiki/Dev_Patel "Dev Patel"), [Daniel Kaluuya](/wiki/Daniel_Kaluuya "Daniel Kaluuya"), [Tom Holland](/wiki/Tom_Holland "Tom Holland"), and [Daniel Day-Lewis](/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis "Daniel Day-Lewis"). Post-war [Ealing comedies](/wiki/Ealing_comedies "Ealing comedies") featured [Alec Guinness](/wiki/Alec_Guinness "Alec Guinness"), from the 1950s [Hammer Horrors](/wiki/Hammer_Film_Productions "Hammer Film Productions") starred [Christopher Lee](/wiki/Christopher_Lee "Christopher Lee"), films directed by [Michael Powell](/wiki/Michael_Powell "Michael Powell") included the London-set early [slasher](/wiki/Slasher_film "Slasher film") *[Peeping Tom](/wiki/Peeping_Tom_(1960_film) "Peeping Tom (1960 film)")* (1960), the 1970s comedy troupe [Monty Python](/wiki/Monty_Python "Monty Python") had film editing suites in Covent Garden, while since the 1990s [Richard Curtis](/wiki/Richard_Curtis "Richard Curtis")'s rom-coms have featured [Hugh Grant](/wiki/Hugh_Grant "Hugh Grant"). The largest cinema chain in the country, [Odeon Cinemas](/wiki/Odeon_Cinemas "Odeon Cinemas") was founded in London in 1928 by [Oscar Deutsch](/wiki/Oscar_Deutsch "Oscar Deutsch").^[\[396\]](#cite_note-405)^ The [BFI IMAX](/wiki/BFI_IMAX "BFI IMAX") on the [South Bank](/wiki/South_Bank "South Bank") is the largest cinema screen in the UK.^[\[397\]](#cite_note-406)^ The [British Academy Film Awards](/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards "British Academy Film Awards") (BAFTAs) have been held in London since 1949, with the [BAFTA Fellowship](/wiki/BAFTA_Fellowship "BAFTA Fellowship") the Academy's highest accolade.^[\[398\]](#cite_note-407)^ Founded in 1957, the [BFI London Film Festival](/wiki/BFI_London_Film_Festival "BFI London Film Festival") takes place over two weeks every October.^[\[399\]](#cite_note-408)^{#cite_ref-408}

London is a major centre for television production, with studios including [Television Centre](/wiki/Television_Centre,_London "Television Centre, London"), [ITV Studios](/wiki/ITV_Studios "ITV Studios"), [Sky Campus](/wiki/Sky_Campus "Sky Campus"), and [Fountain Studios](/wiki/Fountain_Studios "Fountain Studios"); the latter hosted the original talent shows, *[Pop Idol](/wiki/Pop_Idol "Pop Idol")* , *[The X Factor](/wiki/The_X_Factor_(British_TV_series) "The X Factor (British TV series)")* , and *[Britain's Got Talent](/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_Talent "Britain's Got Talent")* (the latter two created by TV personality [Simon Cowell](/wiki/Simon_Cowell "Simon Cowell") who starred as a judge in all three shows), before each format was exported around the world.^[\[400\]](#cite_note-409)^^[\[401\]](#cite_note-410)^ Formerly a franchise of ITV, [Thames Television](/wiki/Thames_Television "Thames Television") featured comedians such as [Benny Hill](/wiki/Benny_Hill "Benny Hill") and [Rowan Atkinson](/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson "Rowan Atkinson") (*[Mr. Bean](/wiki/Mr._Bean "Mr. Bean")* was first screened by Thames), while [Talkback](/wiki/Talkback_(production_company) "Talkback (production company)") produced *[Da Ali G Show](/wiki/Da_Ali_G_Show "Da Ali G Show")* which featured [Sacha Baron Cohen](/wiki/Sacha_Baron_Cohen "Sacha Baron Cohen") as [Ali G](/wiki/Ali_G "Ali G").^[\[402\]](#cite_note-411)^ Many television shows have been set in London, including the popular television soap opera *[EastEnders](/wiki/EastEnders "EastEnders")* .^[\[403\]](#cite_note-412)^{#cite_ref-412}  

### Museums, art galleries and libraries {#Museums.2C_art_galleries_and_libraries}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/240px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg) Aerial view of [Albertopolis](/wiki/Albertopolis "Albertopolis"). The [Albert Memorial](/wiki/Albert_Memorial "Albert Memorial"), [Royal Albert Hall](/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall "Royal Albert Hall"), [Royal Geographical Society](/wiki/Royal_Geographical_Society "Royal Geographical Society"), and [Royal College of Art](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art "Royal College of Art") are visible near the top; [Victoria and Albert Museum](/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum "Victoria and Albert Museum") and [Natural History Museum](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London "Natural History Museum, London") at the lower end; [Imperial College](/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London"), [Royal College of Music](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music "Royal College of Music"), and [Science Museum](/wiki/Science_Museum,_London "Science Museum, London") lying in between.

London is [home to many museums](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_London "List of museums in London"), galleries, and other institutions, many of which are free of admission charges and are major [tourist attractions](/wiki/Tourist_attraction "Tourist attraction") as well as playing a research role. The first of these to be established was the [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum") in [Bloomsbury](/wiki/Bloomsbury "Bloomsbury"), in 1753.^[\[404\]](#cite_note-413)^ Originally containing antiquities, natural history specimens, and the national library, the museum now has 7 million artefacts from around the globe. In 1824, the [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery "National Gallery") was founded to house the British national collection of Western paintings; this now occupies a prominent position in [Trafalgar Square](/wiki/Trafalgar_Square "Trafalgar Square").^[\[405\]](#cite_note-414)^{#cite_ref-414}

The [British Library](/wiki/British_Library "British Library") is the [second largest library](/wiki/List_of_largest_libraries "List of largest libraries") in the world, and the [national library](/wiki/National_library "National library") of the United Kingdom.^[\[406\]](#cite_note-415)^ There are many other research libraries, including the [Wellcome Library](/wiki/Wellcome_Library "Wellcome Library") and [Dana Centre](/wiki/Dana_Library_and_Research_Centre "Dana Library and Research Centre"), as well as [university libraries](/wiki/Academic_library "Academic library"), including the [British Library of Political and Economic Science](/wiki/British_Library_of_Political_and_Economic_Science "British Library of Political and Economic Science") at [LSE](/wiki/London_School_of_Economics "London School of Economics"), the [Abdus Salam Library](/wiki/Imperial_College_London_Abdus_Salam_Library "Imperial College London Abdus Salam Library") at [Imperial](/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London"), the [Maughan Library](/wiki/Maughan_Library "Maughan Library") at [King's](/wiki/King%27s_College_London "King's College London"), and the [Senate House Libraries](/wiki/Senate_House_Libraries "Senate House Libraries") at the [University of London](/wiki/University_of_London "University of London").^[\[407\]](#cite_note-416)^{#cite_ref-416}

In the latter half of the 19th century the locale of [South Kensington](/wiki/South_Kensington "South Kensington") was developed as "[Albertopolis](/wiki/Albertopolis "Albertopolis")", a cultural and scientific quarter. Three major national museums are there: the [Victoria and Albert Museum](/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum "Victoria and Albert Museum"), the [Natural History Museum](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London "Natural History Museum, London"), and the [Science Museum](/wiki/London_Science_Museum "London Science Museum"). The [National Portrait Gallery](/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery,_London "National Portrait Gallery, London") was founded in 1856 to house depictions of figures from British history; its holdings now comprise the world's most extensive collection of portraits.^[\[408\]](#cite_note-417)^ The national gallery of British art is at [Tate Britain](/wiki/Tate_Britain "Tate Britain"), originally established as an annexe of the National Gallery in 1897. The Tate Gallery, as it was formerly known, also became a major centre for modern art. In 2000, this collection moved to [Tate Modern](/wiki/Tate_Modern "Tate Modern"), a new gallery housed in the former [Bankside Power Station](/wiki/Bankside_Power_Station "Bankside Power Station") which is accessed by pedestrians north of the Thames via the [Millennium Bridge](/wiki/Millennium_Bridge,_London "Millennium Bridge, London").^[\[409\]](#cite_note-418)^{#cite_ref-418}  

### Music {#Music}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG/220px-Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG)](/wiki/File:Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG) The [Royal Albert Hall](/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall "Royal Albert Hall") hosts concerts and musical events, including the classical music festival [The Proms](/wiki/BBC_Proms "BBC Proms") which are held every summer, as well as cinema screenings of films accompanied with live orchestral music.

London is one of the major classical and [popular music](/wiki/Popular_music "Popular music") capitals of the world and hosts major music corporations, such as [Universal Music Group International](/wiki/Universal_Music_Group "Universal Music Group") and [Warner Music Group](/wiki/Warner_Music_Group "Warner Music Group"), and countless bands, musicians and industry professionals. The city is also home to many orchestras and concert halls, such as the [Barbican Arts Centre](/wiki/Barbican_Arts_Centre "Barbican Arts Centre") (principal base of the [London Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra "London Symphony Orchestra") and the [London Symphony Chorus](/wiki/London_Symphony_Chorus "London Symphony Chorus")), the [Southbank Centre](/wiki/Southbank_Centre "Southbank Centre") ([London Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/London_Philharmonic_Orchestra "London Philharmonic Orchestra") and the [Philharmonia Orchestra](/wiki/Philharmonia_Orchestra "Philharmonia Orchestra")), [Cadogan Hall](/wiki/Cadogan_Hall "Cadogan Hall") ([Royal Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Royal_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Royal Philharmonic Orchestra")), and the [Royal Albert Hall](/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall "Royal Albert Hall") ([The Proms](/wiki/The_Proms "The Proms")).^[\[358\]](#cite_note-London's_Concerts-367)^ The Proms, an eight-week summer season of daily orchestral classical music first held in 1895, ends with the [Last Night of the Proms](/wiki/BBC_Proms#Last_Night_of_the_Proms "BBC Proms"). London's two main opera houses are the [Royal Opera House](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House "Royal Opera House") and the [London Coliseum](/wiki/London_Coliseum "London Coliseum") (home to the [English National Opera](/wiki/English_National_Opera "English National Opera")).^[\[358\]](#cite_note-London's_Concerts-367)^ The UK's largest [pipe organ](/wiki/Pipe_organ "Pipe organ") is at the Royal Albert Hall. Other significant instruments are in cathedrals and major churches---the church bells of [St Clement Danes](/wiki/St_Clement_Danes "St Clement Danes") feature in the 1744 [nursery rhyme](/wiki/Nursery_rhyme "Nursery rhyme") "[Oranges and Lemons](/wiki/Oranges_and_Lemons "Oranges and Lemons")".^[\[410\]](#cite_note-419)^ Several [conservatoires](/wiki/Conservatoire "Conservatoire") are within the city: [Royal Academy of Music](/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music "Royal Academy of Music"), [Royal College of Music](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music "Royal College of Music"), [Guildhall School of Music and Drama](/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama "Guildhall School of Music and Drama"), and [Trinity Laban](/wiki/Trinity_College_of_Music "Trinity College of Music"). The record label [EMI](/wiki/EMI "EMI") was formed in the city in 1931, and an early employee for the company, [Alan Blumlein](/wiki/Alan_Blumlein "Alan Blumlein"), created [stereo sound](/wiki/Stereo_sound "Stereo sound") that year.^[\[411\]](#cite_note-420)^ Guitar amp engineer [Jim Marshall](/wiki/Jim_Marshall_(businessman) "Jim Marshall (businessman)") founded [Marshall Amplification](/wiki/Marshall_Amplification "Marshall Amplification") in London in 1962.^[\[412\]](#cite_note-421)^{#cite_ref-421}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/250px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg)](/wiki/File:Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg) [Abbey Road Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios "Abbey Road Studios") in [Abbey Road](/wiki/Abbey_Road,_London "Abbey Road, London")

London has numerous venues for rock and pop concerts, including the world's busiest indoor venue, [the O~2~ Arena](/wiki/The_O2_Arena "The O2 Arena"),^[\[413\]](#cite_note-422)^ and [Wembley Arena](/wiki/Wembley_Arena "Wembley Arena"), as well as many mid-sized venues, such as [Brixton Academy](/wiki/Brixton_Academy "Brixton Academy"), the [Hammersmith Apollo](/wiki/Hammersmith_Apollo "Hammersmith Apollo") and the [Shepherd's Bush Empire](/wiki/Shepherd%27s_Bush_Empire "Shepherd's Bush Empire").^[\[358\]](#cite_note-London's_Concerts-367)^ Several [music festivals](/wiki/Music_festivals "Music festivals"), including the [Wireless Festival](/wiki/Wireless_Festival "Wireless Festival"), [Lovebox](/wiki/Lovebox_Festival "Lovebox Festival"), and [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London "Hyde Park, London")'s [British Summer Time](/wiki/British_Summer_Time_(concerts) "British Summer Time (concerts)"), are held in London.^[\[414\]](#cite_note-423)^{#cite_ref-423}

The city is home to the original [Hard Rock Cafe](/wiki/Hard_Rock_Cafe "Hard Rock Cafe") and the [Abbey Road Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios "Abbey Road Studios"), where [the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles") recorded many of their hits. In the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, musicians and groups like [Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John"), [Pink Floyd](/wiki/Pink_Floyd "Pink Floyd"), [David Bowie](/wiki/David_Bowie "David Bowie"), [the Rolling Stones](/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones "The Rolling Stones"), [Queen](/wiki/Queen_(band) "Queen (band)"), [Eric Clapton](/wiki/Eric_Clapton "Eric Clapton"), [the Who](/wiki/The_Who "The Who"), [the Kinks](/wiki/The_Kinks "The Kinks"), [Cliff Richard](/wiki/Cliff_Richard "Cliff Richard"), [Led Zeppelin](/wiki/Led_Zeppelin "Led Zeppelin"), [Iron Maiden](/wiki/Iron_Maiden "Iron Maiden"), [Deep Purple](/wiki/Deep_Purple "Deep Purple"), [T. Rex](/wiki/T._Rex_(band) "T. Rex (band)"), [the Police](/wiki/The_Police "The Police"), [Elvis Costello](/wiki/Elvis_Costello "Elvis Costello"), [Dire Straits](/wiki/Dire_Straits "Dire Straits"), [Cat Stevens](/wiki/Cat_Stevens "Cat Stevens"), [Fleetwood Mac](/wiki/Fleetwood_Mac "Fleetwood Mac"), [the Cure](/wiki/The_Cure "The Cure"), [Madness](/wiki/Madness_(band) "Madness (band)"), [Culture Club](/wiki/Culture_Club "Culture Club"), [Dusty Springfield](/wiki/Dusty_Springfield "Dusty Springfield"), [Phil Collins](/wiki/Phil_Collins "Phil Collins"), [Rod Stewart](/wiki/Rod_Stewart "Rod Stewart"), [Status Quo](/wiki/Status_Quo_(band) "Status Quo (band)"), and [Sade](/wiki/Sade_(band) "Sade (band)"), derived their sound from the streets and rhythms of London.^[\[415\]](#cite_note-424)^^[\[416\]](#cite_note-425)^{#cite_ref-425}

London was instrumental in the development of [punk music](/wiki/Punk_music "Punk music"), with groups such as the [Sex Pistols](/wiki/Sex_Pistols "Sex Pistols"), [the Clash](/wiki/The_Clash "The Clash"), and fashion designer [Vivienne Westwood](/wiki/Vivienne_Westwood "Vivienne Westwood") all based in the city.^[\[417\]](#cite_note-426)^ Other artists to emerge from the London music scene include [George Michael](/wiki/George_Michael "George Michael"), [Kate Bush](/wiki/Kate_Bush "Kate Bush"), [Seal](/wiki/Seal_(musician) "Seal (musician)"), [Siouxsie and the Banshees](/wiki/Siouxsie_and_the_Banshees "Siouxsie and the Banshees"), [Bush](/wiki/Bush_(British_band) "Bush (British band)"), the [Spice Girls](/wiki/Spice_Girls "Spice Girls"), [Jamiroquai](/wiki/Jamiroquai "Jamiroquai"), [Blur](/wiki/Blur_(band) "Blur (band)"), [the Prodigy](/wiki/The_Prodigy "The Prodigy"), [Gorillaz](/wiki/Gorillaz "Gorillaz"), [Mumford \& Sons](/wiki/Mumford_%26_Sons "Mumford & Sons"), [Coldplay](/wiki/Coldplay "Coldplay"), [Dido](/wiki/Dido_(singer) "Dido (singer)"), [Amy Winehouse](/wiki/Amy_Winehouse "Amy Winehouse"), [Adele](/wiki/Adele "Adele"), [Sam Smith](/wiki/Sam_Smith_(singer) "Sam Smith (singer)"), [Ed Sheeran](/wiki/Ed_Sheeran "Ed Sheeran"), [Leona Lewis](/wiki/Leona_Lewis "Leona Lewis"), [Ellie Goulding](/wiki/Ellie_Goulding "Ellie Goulding"), [Dua Lipa](/wiki/Dua_Lipa "Dua Lipa"), and [Florence and the Machine](/wiki/Florence_and_the_Machine "Florence and the Machine").^[\[418\]](#cite_note-Scene-427)^ Artists from London played a prominent role in the development of [synth-pop](/wiki/Synth-pop "Synth-pop"), including [Gary Numan](/wiki/Gary_Numan "Gary Numan"), [Depeche Mode](/wiki/Depeche_Mode "Depeche Mode"), the [Pet Shop Boys](/wiki/Pet_Shop_Boys "Pet Shop Boys"), and [Eurythmics](/wiki/Eurythmics "Eurythmics"); the latter's "[Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)](/wiki/Sweet_Dreams_(Are_Made_of_This) "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)")" was recorded in the attic of their north London home, heralding a trend for home recording methods.^[\[419\]](#cite_note-428)^ Artists from London with a Caribbean influence include [Hot Chocolate](/wiki/Hot_Chocolate "Hot Chocolate"), [Billy Ocean](/wiki/Billy_Ocean "Billy Ocean"), [Soul II Soul](/wiki/Soul_II_Soul "Soul II Soul"), and [Eddy Grant](/wiki/Eddy_Grant "Eddy Grant"), with the latter fusing [reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae"), soul and samba with rock and pop.^[\[420\]](#cite_note-429)^ London is also a centre for urban music. In particular the genres [UK garage](/wiki/UK_garage "UK garage"), [drum and bass](/wiki/Drum_and_bass "Drum and bass"), [dubstep](/wiki/Dubstep "Dubstep"), and [grime](/wiki/Grime_(music) "Grime (music)") evolved in the city from the foreign genres of [house](/wiki/House_music "House music"), [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music"), and reggae, alongside local [drum and bass](/wiki/Drum_and_bass "Drum and bass"). Urban acts from London include [Stormzy](/wiki/Stormzy "Stormzy"), [M.I.A.](/wiki/M.I.A._(rapper) "M.I.A. (rapper)"), [Jay Sean](/wiki/Jay_Sean "Jay Sean"), and [Rita Ora](/wiki/Rita_Ora "Rita Ora"). Music station [BBC Radio 1Xtra](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1Xtra "BBC Radio 1Xtra") was set up to support the rise of local [urban contemporary](/wiki/Urban_contemporary "Urban contemporary") music both in London and in the rest of the United Kingdom. The [British Phonographic Industry](/wiki/British_Phonographic_Industry "British Phonographic Industry")'s annual popular music awards, the [Brit Awards](/wiki/Brit_Awards "Brit Awards"), are held in London.^[\[421\]](#cite_note-430)^{#cite_ref-430}  

Recreation {#Recreation}
------------------------

### Parks and open spaces {#Parks_and_open_spaces}

Main articles: [Parks and open spaces in London](/wiki/Parks_and_open_spaces_in_London "Parks and open spaces in London") and [Royal Parks of London](/wiki/Royal_Parks_of_London "Royal Parks of London")  
See also: [List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London](/wiki/List_of_Sites_of_Special_Scientific_Interest_in_Greater_London "List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London") and [List of local nature reserves in Greater London](/wiki/List_of_local_nature_reserves_in_Greater_London "List of local nature reserves in Greater London")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg/240px-Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg) [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London "Hyde Park, London") (with [Kensington Gardens](/wiki/Kensington_Gardens "Kensington Gardens") in the foreground) has been a popular public space since it opened in 1637.

A 2013 report by the [City of London Corporation](/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation "City of London Corporation") said that London is the "greenest city" in Europe with 35,000 acres (14,164 hectares) of public parks, woodlands and gardens.^[\[422\]](#cite_note-431)^ The largest parks in the [central area of London](/wiki/Central_London "Central London") are three of the eight [Royal Parks](/wiki/Royal_Parks_of_London "Royal Parks of London"), namely [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London "Hyde Park, London") and its neighbour [Kensington Gardens](/wiki/Kensington_Gardens "Kensington Gardens") in the west, and [Regent's Park](/wiki/Regent%27s_Park "Regent's Park") to the north.^[\[423\]](#cite_note-432)^ Hyde Park in particular is popular for [sports](#Sport) and sometimes hosts open-air concerts. Regent's Park contains [London Zoo](/wiki/London_Zoo "London Zoo"), the world's oldest scientific zoo, and is near [Madame Tussauds](/wiki/Madame_Tussauds "Madame Tussauds") wax museum.^[\[424\]](#cite_note-Tussauds-433)^ [Primrose Hill](/wiki/Primrose_Hill "Primrose Hill") is a popular spot from which to view the city skyline.^[\[425\]](#cite_note-434)^{#cite_ref-434}

Close to Hyde Park are smaller Royal Parks, [Green Park](/wiki/Green_Park "Green Park") and [St. James's Park](/wiki/St._James%27s_Park "St. James's Park").^[\[426\]](#cite_note-435)^ A number of large parks lie outside the city centre, including [Hampstead Heath](/wiki/Hampstead_Heath "Hampstead Heath") and the remaining Royal Parks of [Greenwich Park](/wiki/Greenwich_Park "Greenwich Park") to the southeast, and [Bushy Park](/wiki/Bushy_Park "Bushy Park") and [Richmond Park](/wiki/Richmond_Park "Richmond Park") (the largest) to the southwest. [Hampton Court Park](/wiki/Hampton_Court_Park "Hampton Court Park") is also a royal park, but, because it contains a palace, it is administered by the [Historic Royal Palaces](/wiki/Historic_Royal_Palaces "Historic Royal Palaces"), unlike the eight [Royal Parks](/wiki/Royal_Parks_of_London "Royal Parks of London").^[\[427\]](#cite_note-436)^{#cite_ref-436}

Close to Richmond Park is [Kew Gardens](/wiki/Kew_Gardens "Kew Gardens"), which has the world's largest collection of living plants. In 2003, the gardens were put on the [UNESCO](/wiki/United_Nations_Educational,_Scientific_and_Cultural_Organization "United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization") list of [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_of_the_United_Kingdom "List of World Heritage Sites of the United Kingdom").^[\[428\]](#cite_note-437)^ There are also parks administered by London's borough Councils, including [Victoria Park](/wiki/Victoria_Park,_London "Victoria Park, London") in the [East End](/wiki/East_End "East End") and [Battersea Park](/wiki/Battersea_Park "Battersea Park") in the centre. Some more informal, semi-natural open spaces also exist, including [Hampstead Heath](/wiki/Hampstead_Heath "Hampstead Heath") and [Epping Forest](/wiki/Epping_Forest "Epping Forest"),^[\[429\]](#cite_note-Epping-438)^ both controlled by the [City of London Corporation](/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation "City of London Corporation").^[\[430\]](#cite_note-439)^ Hampstead Heath incorporates [Kenwood House](/wiki/Kenwood_House "Kenwood House"), a former [stately home](/wiki/Stately_home "Stately home") and a popular location in the summer months when classical musical concerts are held by the lake.^[\[431\]](#cite_note-440)^ Epping Forest is a popular venue for various outdoor activities, including mountain biking, walking, horse riding, golf, angling, and orienteering.^[\[429\]](#cite_note-Epping-438)^ Three of the UK's most-visited theme parks, [Thorpe Park](/wiki/Thorpe_Park "Thorpe Park") near Staines-upon-Thames, [Chessington World of Adventures](/wiki/Chessington_World_of_Adventures "Chessington World of Adventures") in Chessington and [Legoland Windsor](/wiki/Legoland_Windsor_Resort "Legoland Windsor Resort"), are located within 20 miles (32 km) of London.^[\[432\]](#cite_note-441)^{#cite_ref-441}  

### Walking {#Walking}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg/220px-Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg)](/wiki/File:Horse_Ride,_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg) The Horse Ride is a [tree tunnel](/wiki/Tree_tunnel "Tree tunnel") (route overhung by trees) on the western side of [Wimbledon Common](/wiki/Wimbledon_Common "Wimbledon Common").

[Walking is a popular recreational activity in London](/wiki/Walking_in_London "Walking in London"). Areas that provide for walks include [Wimbledon Common](/wiki/Wimbledon_Common "Wimbledon Common"), [Epping Forest](/wiki/Epping_Forest "Epping Forest"), [Hampton Court Park](/wiki/Hampton_Court_Park "Hampton Court Park"), [Hampstead Heath](/wiki/Hampstead_Heath "Hampstead Heath"), the eight [Royal Parks](/wiki/Royal_Parks "Royal Parks"), [Regents Canal](/wiki/Regents_Canal "Regents Canal") Walk, canals, and disused railway tracks.^[\[433\]](#cite_note-:0-442)^ Access to canals and rivers has improved recently, including the creation of the [Thames Path](/wiki/Thames_Path "Thames Path"), some 28 miles (45 km) of which is within [Greater London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London"), and The [Wandle Trail](/wiki/Wandle_Trail "Wandle Trail") along the [River Wandle](/wiki/River_Wandle "River Wandle").^[\[434\]](#cite_note-443)^{#cite_ref-443}

Other [long-distance paths](/wiki/Long-distance_path "Long-distance path"), linking green spaces, have also been created, including the [Capital Ring](/wiki/Capital_Ring "Capital Ring"), the [Green Chain Walk](/wiki/Green_Chain_Walk "Green Chain Walk"), [London Outer Orbital Path](/wiki/London_Outer_Orbital_Path "London Outer Orbital Path") ("Loop"), [Jubilee Walkway](/wiki/Jubilee_Walkway "Jubilee Walkway"), [Lea Valley Walk](/wiki/Lea_Valley_Walk "Lea Valley Walk"), and the [Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Walk](/wiki/Diana,_Princess_of_Wales_Memorial_Walk "Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Walk").^[\[433\]](#cite_note-:0-442)^{#cite_ref-:0_442-1}  

Sport {#Sport}
--------------

Main article: [Sport in London](/wiki/Sport_in_London "Sport in London")  
See also: [Football in London](/wiki/Football_in_London "Football in London") and [Rugby union in London](/wiki/Rugby_union_in_London "Rugby union in London")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg/215px-Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg)  
[Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium"), home of the England [men](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football team") and [women's football team](/wiki/England_women%27s_national_football_team "England women's national football team") and the [FA Cup Final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final"), has a seating capacity of 90,000. It is the UK's biggest stadium.^[\[435\]](#cite_note-Wembley-444)^  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg/215px-Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg)  
[Centre Court](/wiki/Centre_Court "Centre Court") at [Wimbledon](/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon"). Held every June and July, Wimbledon is the oldest tennis tournament in the world, and the only major played on grass.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg/215px-Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg)](/wiki/File:Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg)  
[Twickenham](/wiki/Twickenham_Stadium "Twickenham Stadium"), home of the [England national rugby union team](/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team "England national rugby union team"), has a capacity of 82,000 seats.

London has hosted the [Summer Olympics](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games") three times: in [1908](/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics "1908 Summer Olympics"), [1948](/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics "1948 Summer Olympics"), and [2012](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics"), making it the first city to host the modern Games three times.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-IOC-42)^ The city was also the host of the [British Empire Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games") in [1934](/wiki/1934_British_Empire_Games "1934 British Empire Games").^[\[436\]](#cite_note-london_175-445)^ In 2017, London hosted the [World Championships in Athletics](/wiki/2017_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2017 World Championships in Athletics") for the first time.^[\[437\]](#cite_note-446)^{#cite_ref-446}

London's [most popular sport](/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom#Popularity "Sport in the United Kingdom") is [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"), and it has seven clubs in the [Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") in the [2023--24 season](/wiki/2023%E2%80%9324_Premier_League "2023–24 Premier League"): [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C."), [Brentford](/wiki/Brentford_F.C. "Brentford F.C."), [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C."), [Crystal Palace](/wiki/Crystal_Palace_F.C. "Crystal Palace F.C."), [Fulham](/wiki/Fulham_F.C. "Fulham F.C."), [Tottenham Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C."), and [West Ham United](/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C. "West Ham United F.C.").^[\[438\]](#cite_note-london_176-447)^ Other professional men's teams in London are [AFC Wimbledon](/wiki/AFC_Wimbledon "AFC Wimbledon"), [Barnet](/wiki/Barnet_F.C. "Barnet F.C."), [Bromley](/wiki/Bromley_F.C. "Bromley F.C."), [Charlton Athletic](/wiki/Charlton_Athletic_F.C. "Charlton Athletic F.C."), [Dagenham \& Redbridge](/wiki/Dagenham_%26_Redbridge_F.C. "Dagenham & Redbridge F.C."), [Leyton Orient](/wiki/Leyton_Orient_F.C. "Leyton Orient F.C."), [Millwall](/wiki/Millwall_F.C. "Millwall F.C."), [Queens Park Rangers](/wiki/Queens_Park_Rangers_F.C. "Queens Park Rangers F.C."), and [Sutton United](/wiki/Sutton_United_F.C. "Sutton United F.C."). Four London-based teams are in the [Women's Super League](/wiki/Women%27s_Super_League "Women's Super League"): [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_W.F.C. "Arsenal W.F.C."), [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C._Women "Chelsea F.C. Women"), [Tottenham](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C._Women "Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Women"), and [West Ham United](/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C._Women "West Ham United F.C. Women").{#cite_ref-london_176_447-0}

Two [Premiership Rugby](/wiki/Premiership_Rugby "Premiership Rugby") union teams are based in Greater London: [Harlequins](/wiki/Harlequin_F.C. "Harlequin F.C.") and [Saracens](/wiki/Saracens_F.C. "Saracens F.C.").^[\[439\]](#cite_note-448)^ [Ealing Trailfinders](/wiki/Ealing_Trailfinders_Rugby_Club "Ealing Trailfinders Rugby Club") and [London Scottish](/wiki/London_Scottish_F.C. "London Scottish F.C.") play in the [RFU Championship](/wiki/RFU_Championship "RFU Championship"); other rugby union clubs in the city include [Richmond](/wiki/Richmond_F.C. "Richmond F.C."), [Rosslyn Park](/wiki/Rosslyn_Park_F.C. "Rosslyn Park F.C."), [Westcombe Park](/wiki/Westcombe_Park_RFC "Westcombe Park RFC"), and [Blackheath](/wiki/Blackheath_F.C. "Blackheath F.C."). [Twickenham Stadium](/wiki/Twickenham_Stadium "Twickenham Stadium") in south-west London hosts home matches for the [England national rugby union team](/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team "England national rugby union team").^[\[440\]](#cite_note-musiccap-449)^ While [rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") is more popular in the north of England, the sport has one professional club in London -- the [London Broncos](/wiki/London_Broncos "London Broncos") who play in the [Super League](/wiki/Super_League "Super League").{#cite_ref-musiccap_449-0}

One of London's best-known annual sports competitions is the [Wimbledon Tennis Championships](/wiki/Wimbledon_Championships "Wimbledon Championships"), held at the [All England Club](/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club "All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club") in the south-western suburb of [Wimbledon](/wiki/Wimbledon,_London "Wimbledon, London") since 1877.^[\[441\]](#cite_note-450)^ Played in late June to early July, it is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and widely considered the most prestigious.^[\[442\]](#cite_note-451)^^[\[443\]](#cite_note-452)^{#cite_ref-452}

London has two [Test cricket](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket") grounds which host the [England cricket team](/wiki/England_cricket_team "England cricket team"), [Lord's](/wiki/Lord%27s "Lord's") (home of [Middlesex C.C.C.](/wiki/Middlesex_County_Cricket_Club "Middlesex County Cricket Club")) and [the Oval](/wiki/The_Oval "The Oval") (home of [Surrey C.C.C.](/wiki/Surrey_County_Cricket_Club "Surrey County Cricket Club")). Lord's has hosted four finals of the [Cricket World Cup](/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup "Cricket World Cup") and is known as the *Home of Cricket* .^[\[444\]](#cite_note-453)^ In golf, the [Wentworth Club](/wiki/Wentworth_Club "Wentworth Club") is located in [Virginia Water](/wiki/Virginia_Water "Virginia Water"), Surrey on the south-west fringes of London, while the closest venue to London that is used as one of the courses for [the Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship"), the oldest major and tournament in golf, is [Royal St George's](/wiki/Royal_St_George%27s_Golf_Club "Royal St George's Golf Club") in Sandwich, Kent.^[\[445\]](#cite_note-454)^ [Alexandra Palace](/wiki/Alexandra_Palace "Alexandra Palace") in north London hosts the [PDC World Darts Championship](/wiki/PDC_World_Darts_Championship "PDC World Darts Championship") and the [Masters](/wiki/Masters_(snooker) "Masters (snooker)") [snooker](/wiki/Snooker "Snooker") tournament. Other key annual events are the mass-participation [London Marathon](/wiki/London_Marathon "London Marathon")^[\[446\]](#cite_note-455)^ and the [University Boat Race](/wiki/University_Boat_Race "University Boat Race") on the Thames contested between [Oxford](/wiki/Oxford_University_Boat_Club "Oxford University Boat Club") and [Cambridge](/wiki/Cambridge_University_Boat_Club "Cambridge University Boat Club").^[\[447\]](#cite_note-456)^{#cite_ref-456}
